campaign.story:
Anchor End will provide local, fresh, and thoughtful sandwiches in a way that is inviting to all the twelve o’clock stomach growls. We will provide the convenience of being mobile, the satisfaction of supporting community, all with approachable, comforting, and familiar flavors. Every sandwich is crafted around our fresh, artisan soft pretzel bun. The same time and care that we put into our sandwich foundation will continue with all of the dressings, roasted meats and non meats alike, and all of the fixings. Seattle needs a sandwich trailer that will highlight the start to finish philosophy that so many of our local restaurants practice. 
Anchor End’s number one priority will always be the customer and their need for a quality product at a reasonable price. The Seattle residents need the convenience of a mobile cafe and sandwich shop to serve delicious, quick, and thoughtful food from morning until late afternoon. This new mobile food business will be started and fully ran by the partnership under twin sisters Amanda Lewis and Jessica Lewis. Both of us will have equal say and shared goals for the overall well being of Anchor End. The focal point of all products starts with our pretzel rolls. Our pretzels are made daily from the production of the dough, to the roll’s shaping, and to the final baking. There is a variety of different dough from which each pretzel sandwich is built upon. These flavors are paired with house-roasted meats, house made condiments, and the freshest of local produce. In addition to our sandwiches, we will also be serving Dirty chips, Shasta and San Pellegrino sodas, and Lighthouse drip coffee.
French toast pretzels. Come on.
 Anchor End will be ran out of a sixteen foot 1969 Shasta 16SC camper trailer. The trailer is currently being converted and L&I approved at Seattle Food Truck Builders in Auburn, Washington. To do the preparation requirements in the space needed, we will be leasing a kitchen space from Special Occasions Catering located in North Seattle. It will be at this location where we will be prepping and cooking the majority of our products before service hours. In addition to serving curbside and at farmers markets, leasing a kitchen will allow us to cater events such as weddings, birthdays, and other parties. Through Anchor End catering, we will be able to provide other services including dessert tables and custom cakes.
With the recent incline in popularity of mobile food all over the country; but specifically even more so in the Pacific Northwest, the existing food truck customer base will be eager for our new idea. Not only will these current mobile food customers be part of our market, but also residents who are seeking a fast, fresh, and quality meal will gravitate toward our menu. Anchor End not only provides for people looking for convenience, but also for those who desire vegan, vegetarian, and gluten-free options. What seems to be lacking and missing a potential customer base in our great city is the availability of a quick and satisfying breakfast. Anchor End will start the day by providing the same thoughtful approach to breakfast sandwiches while continuing on to the mid to later day crowd with lunch.
Homemade gluten free bun with veggie patty
Our "Beefcake" (Steak Sandwich)
 Anchor End is a fun and unique answer to not only a small restaurant, but also to the typical mobile food trucks that are currently around all of Seattle. We will run our business out of a custom retro travel trailer that will be pulled by a truck to every service location. Our look will easily become memorable and help establish our brand. Once our customers see passed our creative exterior, they will find that what also makes Anchor End pleasantly different is our fresh approach to all of the food that we serve. As owners, we strongly believe and practice the process of producing our sandwiches completely from start to finish. We make our pretzel buns and condiments, roast our meats, use local produce, and support our city’s small businesses by selling local coffee drinks. Anchor End shows an edge with our flavor profiles and commitment to producing darn tasty soft pretzel sandwiches!  Compared to Downtown, West, and South Seattle, North Seattle is in need for more mobile food options. With our comforting and thoughtful sandwiches, we will, without a doubt, make a splash in the food world. North Seattle NEEDS Anchor End.
So far, we have:
Our business license
The 'ol 1969 Shasta
A loan to convert our Shasta
Perfected recipes
A commissary kitchen
And all the drive possible!
Business license, yay!
1969 Shasta (before)
 Kickstarter will provide the funds to:
Finish the exterior of the Shasta
Buy the equipment
Get all necessary permits
Pay for the first couple months of the commissary kitchen
Help us fully commit to the success of Anchor End
Any extra funding will go towards our loan
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Opening a mobile food business lends itself to many challenges. Weather can definitely be unpredictable and quickly change your plans. Our custom service window will be cut in order to double as an awning. This covered space won't stop the rain, but it will sure keep more people dry!
Another obstacle can be getting permits for parking. Our plan is to secure specific spots each day of the week so that won't be as much of an issue. A lot of these spots have been chosen on private property so we would have the permission of the owner. We will have a catering license as well, so this will help us with other necessary paperwork or permits.
A common problem is mechanical. Trucks break down all the time and lose precious street time while the truck is in the shop. While still in the planning stages of Anchor End, we decided to go with a tow trailer to avoid this issue. Our thought was that if we have mechanical issues with our vehicle pulling the trailer, we can easily use a different vehicle and not lose business.
Being L&I approved would also be difficult if you're not experienced with code, so that's why we selected a professional food truck builder to avoid any unexpected changes with the interior being up to code.
We are one hundred percent committed to figuring out any challenges that might arise and we will be very flexible after we get funded.

campaign.story:
WE'VE REACHED OUR GOAL!!!! NOW WHAT'S BEYOND $12K?
First off, check out our UPDATES for our heartfelt gratitude message :-) We're humbled by all the support we've received, truly.
As mentioned in our project description (below), we've budgeted for a modest, bare-bones start-up and our Kickstarter goal of $12,000 reflects this. Anything extra we raise will go towards our first month's rent of $2800, and/or enable us to purchase additional DIY supplies and furnishings--all to make Burrasca into a cozy, lively and inviting space in which to dine.
WE'VE SIGNED A LEASE! NOW PLEASE HELP US WITH THE FINAL PUSH TO REACH OUR FUNDING GOAL, PRETTY PRETTY PLEASE
Yes friends, we found the perfect, sweet little space to park Burrasca: 2032 SE Clinton Street. A wonderful neighborhood, with a great vibe. We're very excited. But we're still short of our $12K goal, just a bit. Please help if you can! We'd be so grateful.
Our new home
HEY MOM, LOOK HOW MUCH FUN WE"RE HAVING!
We love serving Paolo's Florentine food to Portlanders so much, we made a music video to prove it! 
THE SONG - THE MESSAGE
"Ciao Mamma" by Jovanotti
"How beautiful it is when there's lots of people and the music makes us all feel so good. It's an aphrodisiac, a revolution--when we can all dance together to a song. Hey Mom, look how much fun I'm having!
How beautiful it is, when the stadium's full and music fills the heavens. It's an aphrodisiac, a revolution.... Hey Mom, look how much fun I'm having!
And when dusk comes, the sun sunk low over the city, [in dancing to the music] we become a single spirit, a single body... Hey Mom, look how much fun I'm having!"
Paolo's mamma back in Florence got the message :-) And to our new friends and dear customers in our beloved adopted city: Hey Portland, look how much fun we're having! Thank you for making this possible! Be sure to watch the video through to the very end for a special performance by Portland's own Unipiper, flaming bagpipes and all.
THE PROJECT: WHAT WE'RE SHOOTING FOR
We hope to turn our successful food cart into a bona fide, sit-down restaurant where folks can enjoy Paolo's rigorously old-school Florentine cuisine without having to subject themselves to Portland's climatic vicissitudes of autumn rain, winter rain, spring rain.... We also want to unleash Burrasca's full potential, allowing Paolo the scope to expand his seasonal menu and bring something truly unique to the collective Portland table.
Your pledges will help with all the start-up costs associated with getting the restaurant of our dreams off the ground. We're searching for the perfect home for Burrasca, and when we find it, WITH YOUR HELP, we'll be in a position to dive right in, roll up our sleeves, and start slinging some of the best darn Florentine eats west of the Arno.
We're on a shoestring budget and we've got most of the start-up costs covered, however we're asking you to help us raise $12,000 so we can meet our deficit in the expenses associated with equipment, furnishing & fixtures, and initial inventory. Know that we're so very grateful for whatever you can manage or care to give, and we thank you advance for your generosity and good will. Grazie mille!!!
How did Burrasca come to be, you ask? Well, once upon a time, in a ramshackle vineyard far, far away....
DOWN AND OUT IN FLORENCE, ITALY
Paolo and I had been living over a decade in the Renaissance capital--his hometown--when it began to feel like a dead end. Paolo's long-held desire to own a restaurant serving the food he grew up eating and felt so passionately about was burning to materialize. We wanted to come back to the States and make it happen but with two children and all the immigration and family issues it was a daunting task, indeed. Nevertheless, we laid our plans, sold our house, barely escaped Italian bureaucracy with our lives (icing on the cake: we were gassed and robbed by thieves in our home on the eve of departure), and in late June 2013 landed in Portland--a city we fell in love with and continue to adore. We were excited about making a new life.
A FOOD CART IS BORN
It made sense to start with a food cart: we could test the waters while hopefully building a following of loyal fans who'd eagerly dine at the restaurant we hoped to one day open. It was a great opportunity to interact directly with customers, creating an immediate and satisfying connection; Paolo came home every night exhausted but fulfilled.
Food Cart of the Year 2014 - Willamette Week
Burrasca the food cart achieved more than we could've hoped for. We got a lot of great press, we'd often sell out, and, most importantly, people seemed genuinely happy to eat whatever Paolo put in front of them, gallantly trying things--like our squid inzimino--that many had never even heard of. The cart's success and the warm welcome and enthusiasm with which Portlanders embraced Paolo's fiercely regional cooking touched us deeply and reinforced our goals of one day getting a restaurant off the ground. 
our gnudi, tortelli, inzimino, cartmade pasta & pappa al pomodoro
READY TO MAKE THE LEAP
In January of this year we closed the cart in order to focus on our dream of going brick and mortar; we've been actively searching for a space that's right for us and feel we're getting close to finding one. With the help of your pledges, we aim to defray certain startup costs and create a casual, lively, warm and welcoming place where Paolo can dish up his native version of comfort food.
WHERE WILL YOUR MONEY GO?
$3000 - Kitchen equipment such as deep fryer, food warmer, etc.
$4000 - Inventory (food & beverage)
$400 - Smallwares (dishes, glassware, silverware)
$4600 - Tables, chairs, lighting, decor (including DIY supplies), signage 
We're budgeting for a pretty bare-bones start-up; anything extra we raise beyond the minimum $12,000 will reimburse Kickstarter's fees and allow us to refine and upgrade certain fixtures and furnishings into the fabulous restaurant space we envision.
WHO ARE WE?
The four of us--including our son Giacomo and daughter Gemma--are a family who loves to laugh, travel together and explore new places and cuisines, while striving to enjoy life and stay conscious of what's truly important. We've never chased material wealth, but prefer to pursue richness of experience: spending time with friends and loved ones, learning all we can about this incredible world, enjoying nature, savoring simple pleasures. We embrace change and have thus embraced our new life--and the launching of what we hope will become a full-fledged family business--in glorious Portland.
Together, Paolo and I have some 45 years' worth of experience in the restaurant biz. Fittingly enough, we met at an Italian restaurant not long after we both moved to San Francisco in the early 90s.
Check out the Burrasca website for more on who we are and what we do!
FROM THE BOTTOM OF OUR HEARTS
Portland, you have been SO good to us, so very supportive and kind--as have our visitors and well-wishers from as far away as Italy. Since we opened our food cart, your appetite, enthusiasm, adventurousness and appreciation has touched us deeply. We are already so grateful. 
As we appeal to your generosity with this campaign, know that any kind of support or pledge is deeply appreciated. If you are as excited about Burrasca going brick & mortar as we are, please share this project with your friends and put a good word in. Our most heartfelt thanks go out to all of you for your help in making this happen. We can't wait to see you in the restaurant! Forza Burrasca!!!!!!!!!
Paolo, Elizabeth, Giacomo and Gemma
MAJOR PROPS
We are eternally grateful to the following fine folks whose support is behind this campaign:
Ken Wilson aka Media Maestro - shot our KS video as well as our awesome music video coming out soon! He totally rocks.
Steven Shomler - writer, food cart champion, mastermind behind Stuff Your Face Productions and our video, author of Portland Food Cart Stories (you'll find our story in this book!), and a dear man who's been behind us from the start. 
The Unipiper - an awesome multitasker! Unicycling, bagpipe-playing, kilt-wearing, smile-inducing: one of the most beloved, unique, homegrown entertainers out there. And the nicest guy you'll meet. Look for him in our forthcoming music video!
Bruce Bauer of Vino Wine Shop - lent us his shop for the shoot and wasn't even scared we'd guzzle the inventory; winemaster of ceremonies at our collaborative pop-up dinners; mensch.
Kathleen Bauer - some of the photo credit goes to this terrific food writer and blogger, a fount of all things food/local/sustainable/delicious and a cherished lunch buddy.
Dyson Demara - owner of HillCrest Vineyards; graciously participated in the filming, sharing his enthusiasm for Paolo's food.
Carina Rumrill - co-owner of The Cheese Plate PDX; generously provided advice, support and laughs, both in KS matters and food cart nitty-gritties.
The Fabulous Burrasca Dancers - stars of our upcoming music video!
Last but certainly not least, huge thanks to Lorenzo Cherubini, aka Jovanotti, one of our absolute favorite Italian musical performers, for graciously letting us use his song "Ciao Mamma" in our music video. Grazie di cuore, Lorenzo!

updates.update_content:
Hello dear friends & supporters,
One year ago today, with YOUR GENEROUS HELP, our project was successfully funded, and not long after—July 14, to be precise—Burrasca opened to the public. Paolo and I wanted to thank you again for your support. Many of you have been in to the restaurant and we've been able to do so in person! We hope you are enjoying Burrasca.
We continue to grow and nurture and learn from the business, the business that you believed in enough to donate financial support. It is very hard work, but it is very rewarding. One thing we've learned is that you can't take anything for granted; you must always strive for excellence and improvement while remaining true to your original vision. Paolo is very satisfied; with our open kitchen he is always popping into the dining room, chatting to guests, suggesting and pouring wine, and literally seeing the happy effect his food has on others.

Hello dear friends and backers,
Burrasca is doing great—we've been open one month as of today and things are humming along very well indeed. It's a lot of hard work and a lot of fun. We've enjoyed seeing many of you in our new digs!
We continue to feel so thankful and grateful for your support. Here are some of the things your money enabled us to buy:

updates.update_userinfo: Now open and loving every minute! And a note about REWARDS...

updates.update_content:
Dear friends, we have been putting your money to very good use these past couple weeks. We've been so busy getting the restaurant ready, we've hardly had time to come up for air. But it's all so exciting, we don't mind.
During this crushing heat wave, the air conditioner decided to give out--just as we were tackling tricky DIY projects like painting. We just got it working yesterday :-P Paolo has organized the kitchen and purchased the equipment he needed, in addition we've procured all the glassware and serve ware necessary to get going. Our artwork is up and looking lovely and we've hung our skull of the Maremman bull we brought with us from Italy. Our signs are up and we're putting the finishing touches on our custom tables--made by a local carpenter, illustrated by a local designer, and painted by yours, truly :) Each table sports the name of a character from our Florence neighborhood, so when you come in, be sure to ask for the low-down on who you're sitting "with". See you soon--watch our Facebook page for opening day news. The website  will be up very soon, too.

The past two weeks have been a whirlwind. We have been purchasing and ordering the supplies we need--thanks to your pledges!
Kitchen items include: two-burner counter-top stove, pasta cooker, pasta cutter & drying rack, deep fryer, pressure cooker, griddle, various utensils, glassware (grappa flights coming--woo hoo!) and plates.
We've also bought paint supplies in order to spruce up the interior, as well as order some lovely photographic prints from Fratelli Alinari in Florence depicting vintage Tuscan life :-) We're getting custom table-tops made from a local carpenter, our signage is in  the works, and we've been lining up all the licenses. So many details to attend to but it's very exciting for us.

updates.update_userinfo: It's a wrap! We did it thanks to all of you.
updates.update_content:
Whew, are we glad it's over! We made and exceeded goal! It's very hard to ask for money, and doing it for 30 days felt awkward indeed. Paolo and I are very grateful for all the support you've shown us and we look forward to seeing you in the new restaurant.
In the coming weeks, we'll begin the process of fulfilling rewards (remember to check your selected reward's estimated delivery date--located on the rewards page--to give you an idea of when to expect it), and we'll also be sending you updates on the space itself and its transformation into Burrasca :-)

updates.update_userinfo: Thanks to all of you, we did it!
updates.update_content:
Yes, dear friends and supporters, this morning we awoke to the good news: our $12K goal has been met, and it is entirely due to you!
Paolo and I are humbled at the outpouring of love and support and enthusiasm you have shown us. With the funds you have contributed, we are committed to creating a warm, casual, inviting and welcoming environment that serves the most authentic and delicious food we can make. We will work hard with what you have given us.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We want to do this right. Even though food truck startup costs are lower than traditional brick and mortar restaurants, they are still significant. We need to invest in insurance coverage, website and logo design, permits and licensing fees, point of sales system, commercial kitchen rental, and accounting and attorney fees. Plus our biggest ticket item, the food truck itself! So we've created this Kickstarter project to get things going.
We've spent months researching the ins and outs of the food truck industry and have worked closely with the Connecticut Small Business Administration to formulate our business plan. Our food truck is the heart and soul of our business and is the most important decision we weill make. We have two options.

Option 1: Purchase an existing equipped food truck. This will be less expensive, but creates a greater risk with equipment and mechanical failures. Used food trucks generally do not come with a warranty on kitchen equipment, truck engines, or generators. A quality used food truck can run from $40k-$50k. 

Option 2: Food Truck Builder. We have four quotes from reputable food truck builders with prices ranging from $53k-$70k. Custom building the CT Provisions food truck will not only give us the luxury of designing our kitchen from the ground up, it will also come with a warranty on all kitchen equipment and engine related issues.

campaign.story:
ROAAAARRRR!!!
We want to create SushiRoar-Bar!!
We are Nahan Shalji and Arzu Tekinbas from the Netherlands, we are two perfectly happy friends, but have this major problem.. 
We are addicted to sushi! You can consider us hardcore sushi-fans and our friends always make fun of us because we cannot live a week without the wonderful taste of seaweed, rice and soy sauce.
You might think.. Well why is this a problem..? Go eat some! 
Well, it isn't that easy in the Netherlands..
We are students
We cannot always afford all-you-can-eat restaurants (most have this concept)
Little boxes of sushi are overpriced
We truly believe that many others have the same problem! 
We want to change the 'sushi-situation' in the Netherlands and we have the right solution! 
How?
We want to create SushiRoar!! 
A lovely small bar where you walk in and can order long sushi-rolls and eat under the delight of Japanese music (or you can also eat on the go). 
The bar only has a capacity for max 6/8 persons and is more or less a grab and go bar. 
The idea is to have a variety of 15 different sorts of long sushi rolls at our bar, you can think of the traditional sushi tastes and new exciting tastes. 
LONG SUSHI-ROLLS yes LONG ROLLS! How genius is that right??  
No cutting involved
No hassle with chopsticks
No spilling on your clothes (and trust me we are champs in spilling food)
Cheap, tasty and easy to eat sushi! 
Location
The city of Utrecht is located in the heart of the Netherlands and is a typical student city and therefore our ideal location for sushi-roar
Sushi roar can solve sooo many problems!:
Poverty (people are spending way too much on expensive sushi)
Unhealthy lifestyles (think of the number of people that would eat sushi roar instead of ordering a burger!)
Hate (No cranky, hungry, depressed people, all loving each other)
Okay.. we admit, it all does sound a bit too serious. But that's the point we are trying to make! We shouldn't take life so serious and enjoy the little things in life! 
Sushi Roar:
Healthy delicious snacks
Affordable sushi
Quick, excellent service
Ideal for people in a rush and want something quick
And maybe,...we can even create WORLD PEACE one day! (well first in the Netherlands....)
Help us with making lives easier!
If you want to give us feedback or you have other questions. 
Feel free to send us an e-mail to: teamsushiroar@gmail.com 
We would love to hear your opinions!

I think the best Kickstarters have the best stories, so let me tell you a story!
It is said that the friends you keep for life you find in college, I have found that to be true. This is one of those stories. The place is Providence, Rhode Island, the time the late 1980's. As the city was opening up the river and revitalizing the downtown. Chance meeting of three young guys who's interests all included cars, art, and beer...I know, big surprise.
Each of us builds things. We have in the past built all kinds of things like racecars, airports and shopping malls. We build important things like high tech helmets for our Special Forces troops and ballistic eye protection. We build beautiful things like homes and environments. We make art that grace the walls of private, public and corporate collections. We have raised the bar, and had the rules changed in places and times when the box was left open enough for us to shine above everybody else. Our work has been on TV and in movies and won national awards. Some has been top secret (Shhh) and others that nobody notices. Our work has enhanced lives, made things run smoother, sold products and most important our work has made people smile.
Down East Lobstah's Mmmm tasty!
Three years ago at Joe's annual clambake that happens at anniversary time (You should see this clambake setup) Joe brings out moonshine Mmmm, Moonshine! "Thinking of opening a business,” he says. "Need a change,” he says.
So I waited, waited because I had been making beer and mead for years. Ready to help, but not wanting to take a friends idea. I was hoping he would want my help. But nothing happened.
"When?" I asked,
"Not now" he says.
"Now?"
"Well, I am busy again"
"Well if you don't, and I start looking into it, you know what will happen." "Yep, sure do" he says. So one-day month or so later I did. Opened up the computer Googled distilling and stared my education, It was time for my change. Sipping everything I can get my hands on helps too and leads to some interesting conversations. Distilling for grins and giggles is different than doing it at an industrial level. All three of us have had very successful businesses.
All three of us have faced the changes that the recession has brought. Our hand crafted, one of a kinds eye on the detail kind of work has gone out of style. Our work has been replaced with cheaper and faster to make products. There is always somebody willing to do it cheaper. In the craft spirits industry, the opposite is true, there we can ply our art and craft and make something memorable and people are willing to spend more on it.
clambake shine
We will be starting a small craft distillery. Small as in all done by hand, every batch the result of boiling batches of grain the old fashioned way. Andy working on making the distillery runs smoothly. Joe's creative genius making sure I haven't forgotten anything and to keep an eye on the numbers for those long-term goals. Sarah is doing the sales. John is doing the distilling. Pam, fearless graphic designer has a team of the most creative people working under her for our design and sales needs.  
We will make is a selection of aged and un-aged products, vodka, OOhh I make a great neutral spirit. rum-mmm, and I have a GREAT spiced rum, with a long familiar, but different finish. Wait till you try it, it will keep you warm at night! Whiskey single malt, aged and full of flavor, good for sipping neat. And of course some 'shine to come first out of our distillery. It will take a full 2 years to get our bourbon to find its way into bottles and into a glass, and when it does, you will be the first invited to enjoy it with us.
And the Money is for
Building. Of course over a third is to build the rewards we said we would create. $1,500 goes to Kickstarter for their service. Rewards will be about a third to build and get them to you $7000. $11,000 will be used to purchase parts, and distilling equipment. Mash cooker, fermenters, water heater, and cooler and a small experimental recipe still. No Vendome still for this group, way too inside the box. If we go over, and I hope we do, we will work at our energy conservation. Each little bit of energy we save, is energy we don't have to pay for. We will use lots of heating and cooling, and are hoping to recycle our waste heat, but that is a challenge. Self-sufficiency is part of the New Hampshire ethos, but it is a tough nut to crack with as much energy as it takes to run a distillery. 
A first version of a business plan is complete. It looks extremely promising with the low NH tax, (relative to the rest of the country). The customer base, are big drinkers (highest in the nation). The trending of the market all lead to a favorable marketplace. We need to attract a group of investors who have a similar desire to create and bring to market a line of spirits that profile the best of New Hampshire and New England. 
Rewards
Rewards Will be so much fun! I can't wait. We will work (work is a strong word here) hard at creating a set of great cocktail recipes for your cocktail party. Each recipe using our unique and distinctive liquor, and each cocktail recipe will have its own full color recipe card. Each of these recipes will have a fun name from one of our Kickstarter supporters. A collection of 25 different recipe cards will be created. From these recipe cards, we will create a volume, bound together to use at your bar. We will create 50 of these signed and numbered as a limited edition for the first 50 who select that pledge. Other pledges will have collections of the recipe cards.  
The Name Game
Here is a card to make s Sassy Sarah Smith. Of course the names of our drinks or liquors haven't been confirmed, but the drink is yummy especially if you have some wild Main Blueberries. Drink one of these and you'll be sassy too!
Cocktail Recipe Card
Name a bottle, name a batch!
Its your bottle, go ahead, put your name on every bottle from one batch from the distillery. Each bottle is hand numbered with a batch and bottle, there is no regulation that says it can't be your name! So go ahead, and name it, make it yours. We will send you a bottle; sadly it has to be empty, Kickstarter rules.
OR how about placing your name on our Kickstarter Thank You Plaque. Immortalized in our tasting room for all to see. Of course it might just be more fun to see your name on one of our drinks, no, make that YOUR drink.
Art Don't Mind
Our labels displayed as wall art framed and ready to hang. Once approved by the Govt. we will make a fine art print of one of the label designs, signed, numbered and matted. You won't find anything like it anywhere.    
The Hand Crafted
Write it down, least you forget with a whiskey bottle inspired Pen made from locally sourced Maple and Toasted Maple. Liz hand turns these pens just for us and inspired by the neck and finish of a whiskey bottle. We will create one just for you, available in a variety of finishes, styles and woods. Hoping to add an Oak bourbon barrel wood to the mix.
Whisky inspired hand crafted Maple pens
My guess is you have NEVER had your drinks out of a hand blown shot glass. I do not make these glasses, sadly but a RISD alum makes them and they have been a staple in my liquor cabinet for a time. Each is unique, a great and fun piece of art glass you can use. If you need more than two, double your pledge for more! Uh, thinking I may need to limit these, they are hand created just for this project!
Hand Made ONE of a kind shot glasses
A hand crafted, blown decanter AND two shot glasses. Yes my same friends, Sarah and Myles are hard at work blowing glass into shapes to go with our fine spirits. One hand crafted decanter and two unique shot glasses that you will NEVER find a duplicate of one .
One of a kind hand made decanter and two glasses
The Garden Connection
Because of our connection to local and whole foods, and Sarah being a master gardener. The Garden Connection reward is working with you on your gardening project, or yard project. We have lots of tools for making your yard or garden look its best and for $1000 you get Sarah and John's labor and the tools and experience we have at hand. Planting, cultivating, Yard leaf & debris cleanup, power washing. Contact us with your questions and we can work together to make your place amazing.
About the market
Did you know New Hampshire is where the cocktail was invented? New Hampshire is the best place to open a distillery. Taxes are very favorable. Most states the taxes on liquor ads 50% to the price of the product. Here in the live free or die state; our largest tax burden is from the federal government. Since the state has all the control over the distribution of liquor, they earn their money as distributors. We will easily fit under the 5000 case limits so we will be able to sell directly from our distillery. This is a great asset, especially if we are able to find the suitable high traffic location. With over half a billion dollars worth of product sold at the NH Liquor Commission every year, we don't need much market share, less than 0.1% in order to garner a generous working profit.
Market analysis as reported by the state of NH Liquor Commission, and by the Distilled Spirits Industry 2014 figures. Spirit sales are up overall by 3.3% nationally and 3.8% in New Hampshire which is a great thing. More importantly, sales of value priced Vodka are steady and overall sales are up, so all the gains in the market are in the premium and super premium brands which is where we would place our products. Whiskey and Rum both have similar results; sales of premium products are showing a greater rate of increase than the budget products. The growth segments are in the 21 to 35 year old age bracket, so as their economic growth happens, they will continue to move they’re purchasing up market. Here are links, check them out for yourself:
http://www.discus.org/assets/1/7/Distilled_Spirits_Industry_Briefing_Feb_3_2015_Final2.pdf
http://www.nh.gov/liquor/AnnualReportFY14.pdf
Small distilleries have less than a 2% market share, and only 700 small craft distilleries in the country at this time (small as in less than 10,000 cases per year). There are only 5 in the state of New Hampshire. The rate of growth in this segment is starting to see the beginning stages of expansion much as the growth of craft breweries started small and in the 80'x and 90's had double-digit growth. So much so that Budweiser is now advertising against the craft breweries. Craft distilling is now poised for the beginning of that kind of growth. There is so much room for growth of a small distillery, but in order to compete we need to get it right, with your help that will be insured.
Trade Group Membership

I do have an aggressive timeline through next July. I have some of the smartest, most creative people on my team. Setbacks are a part of a project of this complexity, but they are factored into the equation, and with the right planning, the challenges and risks are more than manageable.

campaign.story:
My Hopes For A Successful Future
  Hello Y'all, and thank you for taking the time to read about my start up project. If after reading everything, and you have questions please feel free to email me. I am more than willing to answer your questions. I have my Facebook page listed on the links section so you can see the food I will be making in my truck. On the page there is also a menu for you to view. 
I want to start a food truck that serves classic american southern comfort food for the soul. That's a mouthful I know. My menu is definitely a wide variety. I have all types of southern food, including southern BBQ. I did not want to just cater to BBQ, because I have so many other great dishes I know how to make that deserve to be on my menu. You just can't say it's southern unless of course there is BBQ, and boy oh boy, nobody does BBQ like me. I started a Facebook page for Mama's Table so I could start getting the name out there early. Also, every weekend I make items from my menu for people to taste and to show on the page. I did this to show people things to come once I am up and running. 
I'm trying to raise enough money to fund all expenses for the new truck, equipment needed, food, and money to live off of so I can devote 110 percent of my time. I am currently working and scraping by to save to get this underway. Hopefully Kickstarter can help me get everything taken care of.
I have been planning this business for the last year. I simply woke up one day fed up with working for someone. I do not want to work for some company that does not care for me. Most places treat you as expendable, because the job force is so scarce they can turn around and hire someone the next day to replace you. 
I also intend on giving back to those less fortunate. I grew up poor. I mean I was so poor we couldn't afford the "r" in poor, we was po. My little brother Devin showed me an article of a guy out in Philadelphia named Mason Wartman, and he uses a Pay It Forward Board. The board is simple. People can buy items for the homeless in advance, and then a voucher, or post it note, goes on the board for someone less fortunate to cash in later on down the road. I was so impressed with what Mason was doing I Googled his restaurant in Philly, and actually got to speak with Mason. He was very friendly, and then I asked if he wouldn't mind it if I used his idea with my truck. Mason was more than happy to allow me the privilege to do so, and he also gave me a few pointers. I will create a couple of low cost items for my menu that will be low enough to entice someone to Pay It Forward. I included a link to Mason's website to Rosa's Fresh Pizza so you can check out his place and see how the Pay It Forward Board works. 
I have been shopping around for a good used truck. I have a few trucks I found online between $17K-$26K. Luckily there is a really great used restaurant equipment store in Portland I can go to to get what is needed, depending on the truck I get. There seems to be a lot of taco trucks that keep popping up for sale. I'm a haggler, so I am confident if I show up with a fair amount, people will give in. No one says no to money, especially once it is in their face.
The goal is to grow this business into trucks located through-out the NW.  After one year I want to purchase another truck or cart in Portland. Once I have it up and running I want to take my original truck on the road to see which cities in other states I can expand to. 
Another goal is to turn Mama's Table into a brand. I make my own Marinara, BBQ sauce, and Pineapple-Mango marinade. I would like to eventually start jarring, and selling at my trucks. I will also be doing funny t'shirts, hoodies, and aprons for Mama's Table. I have a friend who runs a barber shop, who has a guy who runs a small screen printing business. I am all about buying local and supporting small businesses.  
I'm also partnering with a good friend; Craig Haynes, who makes his own jerk rubs. His companies name is FiMi Kingston. I am including a link for his website so you can check out his business. Craig the owner, devotes a portion of the proceeds he makes to schools in Jamaica, Vietnam, and Oregon. I use Craig's Jamaican Jerk rub for my smoked turkey I make for the Smoked Turkey Dip on my menu. I'm also looking forward to having Craig come through to do tastings at my truck. I believe in helping people who are trying to be entrepreneurs like myself.
Freshness and quality is what I'm about. I will shop locally at Gartner's Meats in Portland. They have fair prices, and great quality in meats. Another place I will be going through is Bob's Red Mill Natural Foods. There I will be getting my flour, cornmeal, beans, and gluten free products. I grew up within a mile of their store, and it is really nice. There you can buy in bulk to cut cost. I live right down the street from Portland Fruit Company. This place is amazing because I can buy in bulk here as well to cut my cost on vegetables and fruits. They have a larger store with more items I can shop at during winter days for wider selections, but for what I am serving it wouldn't be necessary. I have included links to these places for you to view as well.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There are several risks. That's the challenge of starting a business from scratch. I am trying to raise enough money so that I can quit my job and pay my bills, so I can devote 110 percent of my time to my business. I have spoke with many people who have failed in running a food cart or truck, and even recently, someone who was trying to start one. the one thing they all didn't do was quit their job, and commit to their business. I also witnessed some people I worked for in a couple restaurants years ago do that same thing. In order to be successful you have to be there everyday. If I have to hire someone to help, at least I will be there to keep an eye and make sure everything goes the way it's supposed to. Besides, no one can do my food the way I make it. I am going to hire someone to help for prep work mostly. I will never get burned out because if you do what you love, you never have to work a day in your life again. 

Since Kickstarter only allows you to cash in if you raise all the money I am asking bare minimum to buy a used vehicle, and used equipment for my start up. I looked over every option available. I would love to go out and buy a brand new truck with everything I need equipped for $79k, but it is irresponsible of me to do that for my firs time. Later on down the road I am hoping to expand out to more trucks, so I will definitely consider that option then. 

The reason I am going with a truck and not a cart is, I want to be able to go to certain places I have scouted out that are a hit, and no one is around to capitalize on around Portland. Also, if I gain popularity I want to go on the road and visit some other states to try and spread my business out. I would like to open a small cart up someplace, then hit the road with the truck. That way I am still keeping people happy in Portland. 

If I come across portion issues and people want more I will simply incorporate into the menu an up-size option which I can call Papa's Plate. Everyone from the south knows Papa was served first, and he had the larger serving over everyone, but he always waited for Mama to sit down and join the table before eating. A King is only as strong as his Queen. The difference in portions will be the sides will get larger, so that I don't have to use up more of the meats. 

There are always bumps in the road to getting things underway. I am prepared to deal with whatever comes my way. If my opening gets postponed, I will put in the extra time needed to get it as close to my official date as possible. If my permits don't go through, and I am stuck waiting, I will stay on the phone or appear at the business office to get my paperwork and necessary documents out in time. If I cannot get cleared by safety inspection, again I will put in the extra time to thoroughly go through what it is they say I need to get it running, All the things that can go wrong, and possibly will, because that is life, I am ready to take on. I am not afraid of failing, or trying. I am afraid of failing for not trying. 

I'm looking for believers in the american dream, that are willing to believe in me. If you're feeling like, "oh this guy doesn't even have a business yet, why should I back him," that's fine. Can you spare a dollar or two? I would like for everyone who sees this to just donate one dollar. I would like to think this is going to be seen by thousands of people, and one dollar is nothing for most, but something to me.

updates.update_userinfo: Rose's Restaurant New & Used Equipment Supply
updates.update_content:
When I went to Rose's Restaurant Equipment Supply I looked up all items I would need to build a truck. Quite spendy getting things brand new. I also, have their catalog. What's great about Rose's is they have an entire floor of used equipment. Their rule is if they have it in stock and it is used, it is half the price of the new version. So, I can obtain great used equipment for half off or I could gamble with craigslist and try to bargain for used equipment that may not work, where Rose's is guaranteed to work. 
Now for trucks, I can find some between 12 and 20 grand listed, and possibly bargain down for less as well, which I was initially going to do with a stocked truck. Money is cash king, and when you show it to people, they tend to fold for what is needed. I'm not trying to come off as cheap, but I have to stretch every dollar I get in order to put more towards my start up.

campaign.story:
VISION: To make Jamaican Patties readily available , fresh and warm, anytime of the day to a wider segment of the World's Consumers
Goal: To have Distributing Franchises in all 50 States of the U.S within 15-20 years, then systematically spread to other Countries.
            With One Of My Instructor Steve On Graduation Day
WHY AM I DOING THIS? I am doing this because of what patties meant 
to me growing up as a kid in Jamaica and to add something positive to 
the perception of Jamaica and Jamaicans to people all over the world.  
Growing up as teen in Kingston during the 70s, I lived next to a home 
bakery owned by a guy named Jah Lloyd. He baked beef patties and 
bulla. During the summers while on break from school, I would wake 
up to the distinct aroma of delicious beef patties being baked. After 
brushing of my teeth and washing my face I would head over there and 
would gladly helped doing whatever was asked of me, not for pay but 
just to learn what was going on plus to at some point handed a hot patty 
coming right from the oven. To me this was the best thing next to 
someday going to Heaven. Taking the first bite into that patty as some 
of the flakes falls to the ground, gave me a feeling even up to today I 
can't put into words, all I can say is that at that point everything in my 
world was A OK.
How I Felt As A Kid In Jamaica Eating A Patty
As the summer progress, at times I was asked to drop 
off patties to nearby corner stores which I gladly did and at the end of 
the day would check back for returns , more often than not there wasn't 
any to my personal disappointment knowing that I wouldn't have one 
last patty for the day, but certainly not to Jah Lloyd. As time went on I 
learned everything about the business from buying of the products 
needed, preparation, baking, delivering and dealing directly with the 
owners of the stores we delivered to. I developed a passion for it that I 
hold dear even to this day. This went on until the summer of 1979 when 
the violence in Jamaica broke out which abruptly brought an end to the 
operation.The violence greatly restricted our movements which in turn 
cut us off from the majority of the stores we delivered to. At the time I 
didn't put much thought into what I had loss as staying alive took 
precedent over everything else. What I had loss was my dream to 
someday run my own successful patty operation, a dream that was 
revived when I migrated to the U.S in 1989 and saw how guys as 
yourself and people of all race and background liked this little heavenly 
delight that had brought me so much joy as a teen back in Jamaica. 
Even thou the passion was ignite, it took over two decades later for me 
to finally act on my dream, for various reasons, such as furthering my 
education in Business Management, starting a family,and learning the 
rules and regulations of the food industry in the U.S. 
But glad to say my passion is even greater now than ever before. 
Beside my great passion for Jamaican Beef Patties another motivational 
factor for me to bring them mainstream through out the world is, badly 
wanting to see my beloved Island of Jamaica be viewed in a positive 
light by having them exposed to someone as perhaps yourself, who 
wouldn't have otherwise known of them. Something that you can take 
home and share with your family or just grabbing a quick bite with 
friends.True, Jamaica is known for Bob Marley, Reggae, to a lesser 
extent Usain Bolt and dear I say it, Marijuana (just keeping it real) this 
would be a welcome positive addition to what Jamaica is widely 
associated with. Just knowing that you, the potential new customers and 
also for you the ones who have had Jamaican Patties before, can now 
get them on demand and knowing that each time you eat one that you 
are experience what I have been experiencing all my life is the driving 
force that will forever keep me on the pursuit of this dream.
HOW WILL I DO THIS? With the cooperation of as many convenience 
stores as possible, I will make Jamaican Beef Patties as readily 
available as hamburgers are, all over the world. They will be fresh, hot 
and ready to go throughout the day. I have just graduated from a 
renown culinary school in Phoenix, AZ, which the sole purpose of 
attending was to learn the rules and regulations of the food industry 
along with acquiring additional cooking skills that will be of great value to 
me moving forward in my endeavor to achieve this goal. To ensure that 
it reaches you safe, hot and ready to eat, correct procedures has to be 
followed at all times, plus we have to have all the necessary equipment 
needed to do this, in place. 
Making Sure It Reaches You Safe.
Equipment such as warming units at the locations they are to be 
sold, 
Warming Unit
along with Mobile Food Warming Units to transfer the patties from 
bakery to designated locations will be added as well.
Mobile Food Warming Units
Multiple mixing units will also be needed.
Industrial Mixers
What I Am Bringing To The Market. My main concentration will be on 
beef patty these has been proven as the favorite of many. In 
addition, I will also be making available Chicken Patty, Jerk Chicken 
Patty and Veggie Patty all taken from my personal recipes which has 
been tested and liked by all who have had the pleasure to taste them 
and I am pretty sure you will as well.
Total Enjoyment From A Bag!
Enjoyed By Everyone!
Over the years since moving from Jamaica I have developed into an
excellent Chef and has many years of working within the food industry.
The quality and taste of my many dishes has been enjoyed by countless
and its my pleasure to now make it available to a wider segment of 
society. To make this happen it's going to take the help of many and I 
am confident and appreciative  that you will help me to achieve this
goal of mine.
Thanks for reading and and for all of your support.
Justin Walker

"Walker's Jamaican Cuisine" dated and signed by me Justin Walker 
thanking you for your support.  
2. $51.00-$150.00 All in #1 plus a T-Shirt of Walker's Jamaican Cuisine 
personally signed by me.  
3 $151.00-$300.00 All in #1 & #2 plus 5 of my personal recipes.
Ox-Tail, Curry-Goat, Curry- Chicken, Jerk-Chicken and Brown-Stew

OX-TAIL
JERK CHICKEN
CURRY CHICKEN
4. $301.00 up All in #1, #2, and #3 plus my best 3 soup recipes. Red-
peas soup, corned- beef soup and chicken-soup. With these, you will 
be the master chef of your family.

Our solution to this is to, in the beginning, deliver only 50 patties at a time to each location, then monitor sale and time rate and deliver accordingly without excessive cost increase.

We have tested over and over the above mentioned situation and have come up with a suitable solution regarding the maximum time we will allow each patty to be kept in the warmer prior to be sold. We are satisfy with our findings as the result guarantee that the risk will be minimal.

Snappers is a loose meat sandwich shop where we pride ourselves on fresh baked breads, delicious lean meats and farmers market fresh vegetables.
Our blend of spices are mixed in with our meats and given a chance to absorb all the flavours which creates an amazing explosion of mouth watering tastes and aromas. We call it our "snapper beef"

          "The Snapper" - delicious snapper beef tossed in our signature snapper marinara sauce  
          "The Standard" - take some snapper beef, mix in some grilled green peppers and onions and toss it all in our signature snapper marinara sauce
          "The Kahuna" - perfectly cooked snapper beef, add some bacon, ham and pineapple and you have created a Kahuna Snapper
          "The  Chili" - we take our classic "Snapper" and toss in some kidney beans for a mouth watering, taste bud tickling, write home to the family sandwich
          "The Shepard" - we take some Snapper beef, corn, onions and drizzle our beef gravy in every nook and cranny while topping it all of with fluffy mashed potatoes

 Location 1, is large enough to fit between 8-12 tables while also having bar style seating along the front window capable of seating 6 people side by side.  
Location 2, is the smaller shop, we can fit between 4-6 tables while having a shorter bar style seating along the front window capable of seating 4 people side by side comfortably
WHAT THE FUTURE HOLDS

After our third year we plan on launching a Snappers lunch truck to bring our fantastic sandwiches to local markets/events and many of the local fairs.

The project that we are looking at expanding into a space next to an  store.  Our idea is to create a gaming café for the Ohio neighborhood and community.  The intended location is to have the gaming space sitting along a main street in Columbus, Ohio.  The space would be centered along a busy street that is near a high school.  And based on our marketing strategy, we would be able to cater to several yet related demographics.
With technology, social media and face to face communications, we want to help provide a physical extension of a place where gamers and sci-fi enthusiasts would be able to meet, socialize and have fun in an environment that is relaxing and inviting. 
We started with a grassroots way of linking up with those that we could server and in doing so, we realized we have the opportunity to provide more services to the gaming community.
And that is the question we have, what can we do now?
We are building a gaming space with parts of a café, and have come to you in hopes that you could help us make this a reality? 
We Need More Space
We began as an online meet-up of like minds, to be able to meet, discuss and play games in whatever area that we could find...  As we have grown in numbers, we have noticed that we also have the opportunity to expand and support a more grounded experience for people of different, yet similar likes to be able to come to.
And with that, we just need a space to help make it work better.
Why a Gaming Café?
In and around Ohio, as well as in Columbus, we found that gamers, sci-fi enthusiasts and the like would stay in comic shops until closing.  And after that, we too noticed that people would meet up later at restaurants and coffee shops.  The issue with that is that there have been issues with enthusiasts being able to share their likes and interests while eating, snacking as well as getting some coffee.
So we have come to the conclusion that we could invest in both our gamers and the surrounding area, not just Columbus, but Ohio as a whole.  This could be a destination spot for gaming, sci-fi, movies, and more!
Within this investment, in future preparation, we too have made arrangements to bring in locally sourced foods, bands and other products so that we can help to contribute to the economic welfare of our surrounding community.  It’s our goal to also help provide jobs to the surrounding area as well.  Of that, our goal is to get the help of local artists
Why a Kickstarter?
The initial funding for this project would help for us to provide funding for the following, but not limited to: tables, chairs, coffee machine, refrigerator, espresso machines, shelves, musicians’, outdoor signage and more.
Once we begin to meet our funding targets, we will provide more details to you in regards to where we are.  Thanks by the way, we could not do this without you!
Please know that, yes, funding is helpful to our growth.  Though, even if you do not pledge anything, please feel free to share this with others, through social media, email, word of mouth, etc. Please feel free to share this, as it means a lot to us.  And we are grateful regardless for the fact that you listened to what we have to say.
How We Are Able to Reward Everyone Regardless of Wherever You May Be Located
When you pledge a specific amount, your name or company name can be placed on our website’s ‘Founder Page’, as well as a plaque on our ‘Founder’s Wall’ within the café.

Three Sisters Momo is a mobile food start-up launching at the Better Block Project. We are a woman-owned business employing former Bhutanese refugees in the Greater Akron Area. We make Momo; a cabbage and meat stuffed hand-folded dumpling as well as other traditional Nepali dishes. We are committed to being a socially responsible benefit to our community. We source ingredients locally from farmers and other small business owners where possible. We hope to expand and provide flexible employment to refugee mothers from the neighborhood. We are also committed to serving the Vegan and Vegetarian population.
Three Sisters Momo was launched on a shoe string by three sister in laws. We started with a hodgepodge of equipment from our homes and loaned equipment from Stray Dog Cart. (Boy does it confuse people when they come up and we are not selling hot dogs!)  Now we have proven to ourselves that we can make this business work. Akronites do want to eat Nepali dumplings!
So, it is time to buy some equipment. We need $1,800 to purchase a tent, a tarp, NSF pots and pans, a custom built portable sink, a new camp stove (ours has seen better days), two portable table (that we can actually lift ourselves) and a variety of utensils.

Welcome Back to Pumpernickels Deli and Café!
We were founded in 1995 in the Lucan’s Building on the corner of Collingwood Blvd. and Delaware Ave. in the Historic Old West End. We again want to be the meeting place for the Old West End and surrounding area. In 1995 I was encouraged by several business men and women and a great number of neighbors to open the Deli on the corner I ran a very successful business for over 10 years. I had an opportunity to move on to a new project that I felt was a challenge and keep the Deli too. At that time my staff took over running the Deli and did a fine job of it. Things happened in that year that I was unable to do both and I decided to sell the Deli. The new owners were unable to continue on with my dream and the Deli was closed.
Now, however, I am semi-retired and need to do something to help occupy my time.
Again encouraged by many people the dream reappeared and my passion for the Deli was back and so am I. On the corner where the Deli began, sits a great Coffee Shop, The Black Kite, a wonderful gathering place for neighbors and friends. In an effort to revive the business district on the corners of Collingwood Blvd. and Delaware Ave. we have teamed up and will put the area back on the map as a place to go for food, entertainment, shopping, and a true sense of what a neighborhood is all about: the people. We see that people from all over the Toledo area like to come to the Old West End and enjoy having a place to stop off and enjoy a cup of coffee and snack or have lunch and dessert. 
At Pumpernickels we will be picking up where we left off and offering a hearty lunch menu Monday thru Friday with our signature sandwiches, great homemade soups, salads and desserts. Welcoming back our old friends and new alike, our friendly atmosphere and family like surrounding give our guests the feeling of being at home. 
So, why the campaign? We are happy to be open, but we want to do more. To grow we need a hood vent and then we'll really be cooking. With your help we can continue to grow our business and our menu. Our guests and our OWE neighbors are why we are here and we're ready to do more for you!

campaign.story:
nexpaq allows you to easily customize, enhance, and add features to your smartphone through the case. To put it simply: You can add and remove physical “modules” (think Lego bricks with special powers) directly from the back of your case without powering down! 
It's time to allow your phone to do things it was really made for. Unlimited potential all in the palm of your hand.
Each nexpaq case has built-in battery power to boot (1000 mAh). This provides your smartphone with a significant amount of extra juice and powers all of the modules.
 nexpaq is the first, and only, modular technology that can be swapped between Android and iPhone devices. What does this mean? Collect and share modules with other nexpaq users, regardless of their operating system allegiance!
It also means that if you decide to change smartphones you'll still be able to use your modules on your new phone, as long as you have a nexpaq case for it.
If you have an iPhone 6, Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge or Samsung Galaxy S5 then you can use nexpaq. We are looking to expand the lineup so please let us know on our poll [click the link below this] what smartphones you want nexpaq to work with!
 To make this new smartphone model happen we will need a minimum of 1,000 pledges. This means that we need 1,000 of you to back iPhone 6 Plus for it to go into production.
We know that we are being ambitious, and we want to do everything we can to make this new case happen which is why we have a contingency plan.
If iPhone 6 Plus does not achieve 1,000 backers during the next 17 days of the campaign, we will extend the pre-orders (at a higher price) for two months on our website and continue to rally until we get the minimum order amount. We will make sure we keep you updated with how it is getting on and of course if (or hopefully when) we hit the 1,000!
What happens if we don’t get 1,000 backers? If after the 2 months of pre-orders through our website, we do not get the 1,000, we will refund your pledges (minus KickStarter fees).
The batpaq is now available for pledging. It functions the same as a nexpaq case and works with any smartphone. It even has 2600mAh of rechargeable battery!
The batpaq: the first modular battery pack.
The batpaq is the ultimate companion for your smartphone.
Any smartphone. All modules work the same as they do on the nexpaq, connecting via usb cable or even wireless Bluetooth. The batpaq fits conveniently in your pocket or handbag.
Just some of what's possible with batpaq:
Slide 1 or 2 Amplified Speaker modules in for a remote audio device.
 With Hotkey modules it becomes a remote control for your phone (even for pictures and selfies)  
Stack USB, Backup, or SD card modules and make it a storage drive.
Make it a super power bank by stacking battery modules, or use it to recharge them.  
Stack Air Quality and Temperature and Humidity modules to get remote information
1. Put your phone in the nexpaq case
2. Choose your modules and slide them in
3. Start the app and control your modules  

You can access all of your modules through the app. Simply click on the module to check a reading of how much storage and battery you have. When you swap in a new module, the app will automatically update so you can get going straight away.

 Even if your case is not attached to your phone, you can still switch on the case and remotely control the modules via bluetooth from your nexpaq app.
There are 12 modules currently available including: 
Click the image above for module details
 AND THIS IS JUST THE BEGINNING…... It's important for us to build an open platform so *you* can dream up module ideas and developers make them a reality!! 
New modules will become available on our hardware app store.
The four modules in each set are enough to entirely fill the 6 slots of the nexpaq case.(The battery module takes 3 slots)
However you can add as many modules to your reward as you want, you simply need to add their corresponding amounts to your pledge.
 For example: one laser + one extra battery = 14 usd + 14 usd = 28 usd (afterwards we will contact you to confirm your module choice)
 This is how we’ve got to where we are today and our future plans:
If you want to be one of the first to get your hands on nexpaq, then this is for you. We want to give you early access and hear your feedback. The Beta version is actually not that Beta, it retains exactly the same functionality as the regular nexpaq and is compatible with many of the same modules including:
 * Hot key module
* LED module  
* Temperature and humidity module  
* Pollution module  
* Breathalyser module
* Laser module
* Battery module
A lot of heart went into nexpaq’s design. The key was to keep your phone looking good while packing in lots of functions. Take a look at these few design concepts and mock ups from the last 18 months:
The journey doesn't end when you receive your nexpaq and starter modules.  We've built nexpaq from the ground up as a device from and for the people.
The Developer Kit is the first step in cultivating an ever-growing community that will bring nexpaq to limits we've only yet dreamed of. We will also be building a modular ecosystem and the first hardware app store (think Google Play but for modules) that brings users and developers together to share ideas and create new modules that will truly let everyone get what they want out of their smartphone.
Developers, here is your call to action. Grab a kit and from day one and start creating modules that will usher in an amazing era.
We worked hard to complete all the R&D and now we need you to help us to finalize design production and purchase tooling for mass production. 
We are excited to be the first company to create a modular smartcase solution and we think that Kickstarter is the perfect place to get feedback on our product and help us bring it to market.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Any hardware products, especially a modular general purpose product like nexpaq, comes with its risks and challenges. The nexpaq team has been working hard to address every one of them so we can deliver a high quality product which fulfills your expectations and more.

Our first priority is the reliability and longevity of our product, specifically all of the components that move, slide, and plug in and out. We have already made more than 100 designs and prototypes to select the best working and looking. We will repeat all lifetime tests under different conditions, 10,000 cycles or more with the final tooling before mass production.

Our next, but top, priority is to provide an easy to use modular product which is highly customizable and where the modules work identically, cross-platform for Android, iOS and for any upcoming future operating systems. Our technology is developed, tested and working on Samsung Galaxy S4, S5, S6 and iPhone 5 and 6.

Our team has great experience in developing products from the ground up, leading to mass production and we are confident that we’ll be able to deliver a great product and overcome any other challenges.

C.H.I.P. is a computer for students, teachers, grandparents, children, artists, makers, hackers, and inventors. Everyone really. C.H.I.P. is a great way to add a computer to your life and the perfect way to power your computer based projects.
C.H.I.P. has built in WiFi + Bluetooth. Connect to the internet and attach a keyboard and mouse WIRELESSLY!  
C.H.I.P. is designed to work with any screen. Old or new. Big or small.
Connect via C.H.I.P.’s built-in composite output or add a simple adapter for either VGA or HDMI.
Use C.H.I.P. with LibreOffice to edit spreadsheets, create word documents, or craft presentations. It's all there. 
Use the Chromium browser to surf the web. Check out websites, send emails, watch videos, and more. The internet awaits. 
C.H.I.P. comes pre-loaded with Scratch - an easy to learn language that teaches the basics of programing by making stories, games, and animations. 
Connect bluetooth controllers to C.H.I.P. and play thousands of games both retro and new. Been missing that amazing DOS game from your childhood? C.H.I.P. plays it! 
Connect a MIDI keyboard to C.H.I.P. and jam. Use it as a portable music player or as part of your favorite setup. Attach powered speakers and hear your tunes at full volume.  Rock on! 
C.H.I.P.'s open source operating system is easy to use and navigate. Its graphical display is just like what you're used to!
C.H.I.P. comes preinstalled with dozens of useful applications, tools and amazing games. Beyond those, C.H.I.P. can run THOUSANDS of free applications from the open source community. 
PocketC.H.I.P. makes C.H.I.P. portable!  PocketC.H.I.P. gives C.H.I.P. a 4.3” touchscreen, QWERTY keyboard, and 5-hour battery - in a case small enough to fit in your back pocket.
SPECS
3,000 mAH battery 
4.3" 470px x 272px screen w/ resistive touch 
Full Super-Clicky QWERTY keyboard 
Rugged Injection Molded Shell 
Fully open source 
GPIO breakouts 
C.H.I.P. is removable via hatch
USING PocketC.H.I.P. WITH C.H.I.P.
At 1Ghz and with 512MB of DDR3 RAM, C.H.I.P. is powerful enough to run real software, and handle the demands of a full GUI just as well as it handles attached hardware. Best of all, CHIP runs mainline Linux, which means it’s easier than ever to keep teaching it new tricks without inheriting a pile of kernel patches. 
Speaking of power, C.H.I.P. includes a fully integrated battery power circuit so that you can take your project outside right away. No external power circuit needed, just attach a 3.7v LiPo battery to C.H.I.P. and you’re ready to go mobile. 
Most important, though, is that C.H.I.P. is built to be flexible. Whether you’re building yourself a wall clock that counts down time to the next bus at your stop, or setting up a network of hundreds of solar-powered air quality sensors for use in disaster relief, you need the same basic tools to start from: a processor, a way to exchange data, and a way to power everything. With C.H.I.P., all the groundwork is laid, and the only question is what you’ll do next.
We built C.H.I.P. to make tiny powerful computers more accessible and easier to use. A huge part of making C.H.I.P. accessible is making sure that it can change to meet the needs of the community. That's why both C.H.I.P. and PocketC.H.I.P. are both TOTALLY OPEN SOURCE. This means all hardware design files schematic, PCB layout and bill of materials are free for you the community to download, modify and use.
Can’t wait to get started developing on C.H.I.P.? Join our team! By backing at the Kernel Hacker level, you’ll get one of the first 1000 pre-release "Alpha" C.H.I.P. prototypes, hot off the reflow line *THIS SEPTEMBER* PLUS you’ll be first in line for five C.H.I.P.s and one PocketC.H.I.P. as soon as they are ready. This is a special backer level meant only for hardcore linux devs who want to make meaningful contributions toward helping us build C.H.I.P.’s kernel software. If that sounds like the kind of challenge you’d like to sink your teeth into, back at the Kernel Hacker level, and join us on the march towards open source glory! ╭( ･ㅂ･)و
We've worked very closely with the amazing team at Allwinner Technology to insure that all the necessary documentation and source code for the System on Chip and Power Management Chips used in C.H.I.P. will be available for the community to use and learn from.
At Next Thing Co. we love to make things. The only thing we love more than making, is sharing what we make. We're so excited to see what you'll do with a $9 computer.
It takes more than the whole Next Thing Co. team to make C.H.I.P. possible. These are a few of the many amazing folks who have helped along the way: The entire Allwinner team (Ben, Wang Kang, Yinwei, Jet), Our endlessly supportive investors and mentors (Brownell, Cyril, Sean, Ryan, Brad and the FGAngels crew), all of our OTTO Kickstarter backers, the whole HAXLR8R squad - Duncan, Ben, Peter, Qiyu, Atomman and Sally, the wonderful folks at Bay Area Circuits, FATHOM, Kilovolt Coffee, and our families, who have supported us through long nights and endless trips to China.
Thanks!

campaign.story:
The story of #LovetheWall is one of first impressions. There's so much energy and positive activity happening in Downtown Akron just under the surface. #LovetheWall is a way to bring a burst of color to one of Downtown's main entryways and enhance people's lives on a daily basis.
Downtown is the heart of Akron; the living room of the community. It's where we come together to work, experience arts and culture, enjoy a meal, and connect with the community. It's home to the Akron Civic Theatre, Akron Art Museum, Akron-Summit County Public Library, Lock 3 and an incredibly eclectic mix of diverse, independently owned businesses.
South Broadway is a major entry point into Downtown Akron. Everyday, more than 10,000 vehicles pass The Wall (located between the Robert K. Pfaff METRO RTA Transit Center and The Depot Apartments). The Wall is very large in size and has a formidable presence as you enter Downtown. This public art project would serve as a welcome to Downtown, announcing to drivers and pedestrians that they have arrived in a place of importance, a place that matters, and a place we love.
Local artist Nathan Mayfield created the simple geometric design, which will incorporate mirrored stainless steel, inspired by international artist El Anatsui. The simple but classic look of the shapes will allow for a colorful, timeless, and vibrant design that fits the space and the traffic flow.
Mockup of finished mural by Mayfield.
The stainless steel panels, represented in the mockup by light blue panels and arrows, were inspired by El Anatsui's Broken Bridge displayed here:
El Anatsui's Broken Bridge, from New York Times, photo credit Erik Lasalle, Courtesy of the artist and Jack Shainman Gallery, New York
Mayfield has completed planters in Downtown Akron with a similar design:
Planters near 47 N. Main St. designed and painted by Mayfield

Mayfield, an Akron native, is excited about transforming Downtown. "I've lived in Akron my entire life. I've seen it go through a lot of changes. It's always been able to reinvent itself."
Mayfield remembers seeing a mural as a kid on the corner of West Bartges and Main Street, thinking to himself that he'd like to paint the city one day. #LovetheWall is his opportunity to give back to Akron. He hopes the project will help attract people back to Akron and realize that this city is still ever changing. He hopes to engage supporters to bring a large scale burst of art, color and investment to show that the fire is still alive here.
See below for the budget breakdown:
Tools and Materials $700
Equipment Rentals $700
Donor recognition $600
Paint $2,500
Stainless Steel $5,500
Artist Fee $2,000
Kickstarter Fees $1,000
Insurance $1,000
Total: $14,000
Exciting things happen when people work together. #LovetheWall is your opportunity to leave your stamp on the city.
The Downtown Akron Partnership Emerging Leaders would like to express our heartfelt thanks to Anthony Codispoti at Wolfstreet Creative for all of the time, talent, and energy he spent helping us put our video together for this campaign. For more information on how Wolfstreet Creative can help you put your passion to film, please visit  www.WolfstreetCreative.com.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The major obstacle to implementation of the project will be the execution of the timeline. Painting and installation are completely weather dependent and the number of warm, dry days will directly impact the ability to complete the project by the end of June. 

The installation of the large stainless steel panels we are using may be challenging, as well. Committee volunteers will be available to assist the artist in installation and work through challenges as they arise.

The committee, along with community volunteers, has already begun to prep the wall for mural installation. (The prep work will most likely be complete before the Kickstarter campaign is finished).

updates.update_content:
Hello #LovetheWall supporters:
Thank you for your support of #LovetheWall! This past June was the fourth rainiest on record in the Akron area. The wet weather has delayed our start a little but we are excited for a dry forecast and for painting to begin this week.
Thank you again for supporting #LovetheWall. Follow our progress on www.downtownakron.com/myakron.

On behalf of Downtown Akron Partnership and Downtown Akron Partnership Emerging Leaders, we want to sincerely thank you for your support of #LovetheWall. There is something incredibly powerful about the community coming together to make a collective impact in Downtown and Akron as a whole.
This project would not be possible without your support. The committee is dedicated to producing a high quality work of art that will make a lasting impact in Downtown. Work will begin immediately on the wall, with the goal of the mural being complete by early July.

In 2011 South Sudan gained independence from Sudan, but now they are at war again. President Salva Kiir, who is Dinka, disagreed with the Vice President Riek Machar, who is Nuer (a rival tribe of the Dinka), causing another Civil War. Because of the Civil War, the people in Piol, South Sudan had to leave, and they were not able to return until after the crop season. They are now in danger of experiencing one of the biggest famines in history. Many people may die of starvation. Also, many people's homes are being raided. This is why we want to raise money. We want to donate food plus a fence to keep out rebel soldiers from the war. Please help support South Sudan. Every penny helps!
Poil, South Sudan (Thank you to everyone who donated to the Clinic)
Recently a clinic was built in Piol. Around 1 in every 16 kids die, making South Sudan's infant mortality rate one of the highest in the world. Now that they have a clinic, they need your support to get food because they missed the growing season this year due to the war. Any money you can donate will help a lot!
Last shipment of food was awhile ago
One hundred twenty-five dollars is just a starting place. The more money we raise, the better. There is a use for every single penny. Each shipment is very expensive, but with your support and the support of others from the community, we can make a difference. Please share this project and explain to friends how they can help South Sudan. Thank you so much and Piol really does appreciate your support.    
Food that Piol received
