campaign.story:
Thanks to a shipping error at DHL, the prototype we sent to Rahdo ended up in Spain, so no Run Thru review.  However, Rahdo did play a full game of Skyway Robbery at GenCon and here are his thoughts... 
PLAY

.
You are a passenger on a gigantic airship cruise liner on a tour that will take you to the far corners of the Gaslight Empire. You are also an up and coming criminal mastermind seeking to build a reputation as a kingpin of crime. As the airship progresses to various exotic locales, amazing criminal opportunities will unfold before your eyes. Your task is to assemble the best gang of professional criminals, conduct daring robberies, elude various defenses and protect your turf from other nefarious crooks skulking in the shadows. Earn the most feared reputation and take your rightful place at the top of the criminal world.
Unlike most Kickstarter Projects, Skyway Robbery has no stretch goals. To borrow a line from Doc Brown, "Where we're going, we don't need stretch goals!" Skyway Robbery is totally pre-stretched with the best components we can get -- springy ivorycore cards, thick 4mm punchboard tokens and player boards, beautiful laser-etched custom dice, a huge full-color game board. Skyway Robbery is excellent, right from the start!
As mentioned above, there are no stretch goals for this project since Skyway Robbery already comes with excellent components right from the start. Even so, there's room for upgrades, so the Deluxe edition exists to fill that need. In addition to everything in the retail edition, the Deluxe edition includes 122 custom wooden tokens to make your play experiences even more tactile and fun.
Here's a short video that hits the basic concepts of how to play Skyway Robbery. As any crook will tell you, it takes practice to pick a pocket and get away scot-free, and Skyway Robbery is no different. You'll get nabbed by the constables or ratted out by your "friends" more than a few times before you get your air-legs. 
PLAY

                                                                                      The rules are still undergoing fine tuning but you can certainly get a good feel for the game by clicking the header above to download the advanced prototype rules document.
Skyway Robbery is not a small game and it can't be all black and white, but if you'd like to put in the time and ink to make up a print and play copy for yourself, you'll find everything you need by clicking the header above to download the 245MB zip file.
Four advance prototypes were prepared with all of the game art and the most current rules and they've been making the rounds to a chain of reviewers in the USA and UK over the last five weeks. As reviews get posted, they'll be linked below. 
I was immediately attracted to this game given how it takes the idea of a train heist and infuses it with steampunk flair, but was even more excited to find all of this serviced by such a fun experience throughout. -- Jason Dobson, Indie Cardboard.
In this edition of The Game of Crowd Funding Written Interviews, we have a returning guest. Philip duBarry was a guest on the podcast. He’s a man with several games under his belt. And he’s got another project, Skyway Robbery, on Kickstarter right now. -- Jeff King, All Us Geeks.
Being able to choose my actions independently of what others are doing is great. This allows me to see how well I can play a game, regardless of what the others are doing (on a turn by turn basis). -- Jacob Coon, Whose Turn Is It Anyway?
It’s got amazing art. What’s very cool about it is that you’ve got variable player powers, as well. There’s a lot of cool interactions, and you’re jockeying with people when you want to get some money, or get more people for your gang, or rat on the other players. — Dan Patriss, The Geek Allstars @ 2:31:07 mark
Firestone—Of course, it all comes down to how much fun the game is, right? I thought this had a high fun factor! I enjoyed what I was doing. I enjoyed seeing what cards came out. I enjoyed figuring out which Action cards to play--and in which order to play them. I enjoyed the tension of wondering if I'd get to grab that Loot before my opponents. I enjoyed the theme, and the artwork, and the setting. This was a fun game!
Jeremiah— Yeah, there really is a TON going on in this game, and it is ALL really FUN! I loved the meta game that takes place when trying to figure out what your opponents are going to do and trying to play your Actions to both benefit yourself and foil their plans--lots of great and fun tension around that! It's a good, solid game that's seriously a ton of fun!
-- Theology Of Games
The artwork for this game looks totally terrific and the theme sounds very good fun, there’s no doubt of that. But I wanted to find out more about it and the design and designer behind this game, so I got together with Phil and asked him a ton of questions. Paco Jaen Garcia -- G*M*S Magazine Podcast
WOW! This Game is gorgeous! It's getting a lot of great feedback and it looks fantastic. -- Anthony Racano, Cardboartd Jungle Bonus Interview Podcast
...it’s impressive how well the game integrates its themes with its simple mechanics; it’s easily the game’s best feature. For instance, each Location board comes with local gang members and equipment that tailor specifically to the job at hand. This reinforces the idea that you’re actually out on the docks recruiting those assets. Now if they get pinched later on…eh, they’ve served their purpose. -- Ryan LaFlamme, Cardboard Republic
Off-The-Cuff Gaming is all about showing games and gaming in its rawest form. We're not here to review games or even teach you them - just give you a taste. Skyway Robbery was enjoyable game, clearly shown by the fact we immediately played again! -- Tom Tempest, Off-The-Cuff Gaming
                          Skyway Robbery is his new game set in a cool steam punk universe with some incredible art and design, you take the role of a criminal mastermind out to bring some robin hood style justice by assembling the best gang of profession criminals and conducting daring robberies aboard airships -- Who Dares, Rolls Podcast Interview
When I saw that Skyway Robbery popped up on Kickstarter. I jumped immediately onto that game because your tradition of those truly rich and thematic games and high quality components is really a great mark for the board game industry. --  Chris, Kick The Habit Podcast Episode 11
CLICK for PODCAST. We played [Skyway Robbery] again last night as a 4-player game, it was bloody AWESOME. One of the guys barely sat in his seat for the entire game. -- Michael Fox, Little Metal Dog Show
Steampunk style japes and scrapes? YES. 
Intriguing game mechanics? YES. 
Traveling to exotic fantasy locations? YES. 
Stealing treasure. YES. 
Gorgeous artwork. YES. 
Characters wearing snappy clothing!? YES!
So… if a life of steampunk heists, gambits and risk is what you crave, then let us leap into adventure and commit the crimes of… Skyway Robbery -- Thomas Brown, Beasts Of War 
J.R. Honeycut of the DFW Nerd Nighters interviews Philip duBarry about Skyway Robbery. Learn about the game, Philips design process, the art, and what's next on Philip's design calendar. -- J.R. Honeycut, Back It
                                All in all I like this game a lot. Gamplay, theme and artwork all complement each other. This, combined with the idea of assembling a crew of professionals to take what isn't rightfully yours makes this game unique in its own way. -- Mathias Heilmann (Heilz on BGG)
.
My name is Philip duBarry, and I’ve been designing board games my whole life. I grew up playing the classics: Monopoly, Risk, Chess, Stratego and various card games. My dad would crush me at these games nearly every night, but as I grew up I started catching on and holding my own. Some of my first games were roll-and-move affairs involving fantastical monsters. In my teenage years, I fell in love with Axis & Allies and later made a few war games.
After college, I moved to Cincinnati where I discovered a thriving Axis & Allies group. One night after a session of A&A, our host brought out a copy of Settlers of Catan. I had never played a game like that before—it rocked my world! I spent the next few years playing as many modern games as I could. In 2007 I was struck by an entirely new idea for a game: something that modeled the political intrigue I read about in a Patrick O’Brien novel. I designed Revolution! Strangely, my family and friends actually wanted to play this game. I took it as a sign.
I spent much of 2008 making copies of the game by hand and selling them on the Internet. One copy was purchased by Phil Reed of Steve Jackson Games. He called me with an offer to publish the game. So began my amazing adventure of designing board games. My published games include: Revolution!, Revolution!: The Palace, Kingdom of Solomon, Courtier, Canalis, and Family Vacation. More titles will be soon added to this list. Thanks to all the folks who have enjoyed my games! I would appreciate your support of Skyway Robbery, my most expansive and ambitious design to date!

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Skyway Robbery has been in development for nearly two years and things on this end are pretty much all worked out. The printer has vast experience with custom dice, thick punchboard, and quality game cards. The artists and graphic designers have done an amazing job on bringing Skyway Robbery to life. The only thing left to acquire is the funding to get the game printed. 

You might be thinking that since all this preliminary work has been done, Skyway Robbery will be printed regardless of the funding, but this just isn't so. If this project fails the art will be sold off for use in other games and Skyway Robbery will go on the shelf of unpublished designs.

Assuming Skyway Robbery does reach its goal, there's a generous production schedule to allow plenty of time for snags and delays. Then, when it is all complete, EU backers will have their copies mail to them from the UK to save the costs of VAT and import fees.

No one can foresee every possible bump in the road, but with the preliminary work that's been completed and with your patience and support, Skyway Robbery will sail smoothly through any turbulence to land safely on your gaming table.

campaign.story:
You will be amazed by the marvel that is the world’s only Life Sized Game of Mousetrap, a hand-built Rube Goldberg Machine of epic proportions that uses bowling balls, a cast iron bathtub and a hand-built crane to drop a two ton bank safe-proving once and for all that there is a better way to build a Mousetrap!
The Life Size Mousetrap currently travels the US bringing science and fun to folks everywhere. The fantastic interactive installation shows people that anything is possible, that you don't have to have a degree in engineering to understand how to build a crane, and that back yard tinkering is fun!  Children and adults all across America have delighted in the antics of this old fashion vaudevillian style road show for a wacky and wondrous experience that is as educational as it is a feast for the eyes. Mark Perez built the Mousetrap over a 13 year period and has become an inspiration for backyard builders, makers, DIY'ers, and budding young engineers and physicists.
We have three underfunded components of the Mousetrap production that we are seeking donations to ensure the success of this project.  The fourth is a stretch goal that we are personally invested in that would benefit the larger DIY Maker and educational communities.
1) To complete a much needed retrofit on the actual Mousetrap sculpture and hardware.
2) To fully develop our STEM curriculum. 
3) To provide direct tour support for NYC and Milwaukee Maker Faires 2014.
4) To help create a database/network within the Maker Community that would facilitate financial viability for hosting projects where resources are limited  — this is a part of our stretch goal when we pass the $8,000 bench mark.
Now in its 9th touring year, the Life Size Mousetrap has taken quite a beating on its annual travels across the United States. The components for the entire 25 ton contraption are unloaded, built, and operated, then broken down and loaded back into a semi-trailer at least 6 times a year. The sculpture's parts bounce around, bend, break, wear out and bolts are lost.   With the massive size of the whole shebang , show budgets never cover production costs (without fail we go out of pocket every year) let alone the upkeep and maintenance required to keep the Mousetrap in action.  We needed a solution to keep the Mousetrap rolling!
Than the match made in heaven happened, Liquid Wrench of all companies out there stepped up to help the Mousetrap.  They saw potential in me, my crew and what the Mousetrap brings to the greater community.   With a grant from Liquid Wrench and space provided by NIMBY art space,  I began a much needed retro fit of the Mousetrap in the spring of 2014. The task was so large and costly that after 11 weeks of concentrated effort several crucial retro fit items remain unfinished. We have made huge improvements- we rebuilt the Crazy Stairs from top to bottom, and created new art for the chain reaction.  We did tons of welding, sanding, & painting and with the magic of the wheel and axle managed to take an entire day off of our set-up with some strategic streamlining. There is great forward momentum with this retrofit and we are so close to reaching our goal, we just need one last push to make it over the mountain! We need your help to continue the retrofit!
The second component of our goal is to further develop our STEM outreach. The acronym STEM stands for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics. It is the process of teaching that integrates these four disciplines to promote real-world experience, teamwork, and the authentic application of technology. Additionally, it also promotes discovery, problem-based learning, and project-based learning. In order to be educated and engaged citizens of the world in the 21st century, everyone needs to know and understand the basics of STEM. 
In these times of seemingly endless virtual and digital experience, it is crucial for people to have real life encounters with the scientific principles that govern our world. The Life Size Mousetrap offers just that. We showcase the six simple machines and how they work, kinetic and stored energy, and certainly not least of all, gravity! The role of Informal Science Education is critical, a 2009 study by the National Research Council confirms that exposure to Informal Science Education enables students to grasp concepts faster and more easily. 
 We have developed a basic curriculum that we share with the educational programs we partner with but we'd love to expand that into video shorts that educators can use when they don't have access to the actual Life Size Mousetrap. We would like to film these when we are set up at the New York Maker Faire at the Hall of science. With all that said, our mission is to use the power of large-scale kinetic art and the six simple machines to prove that gravity still works! "Physics brought to life," I say, and "lets bring 25 tons of Newtonian mechanics to a city near you!"
The third goal is 2014 tour support.  We are excited to bring the Mousetrap's brand of engineering fun to the Milwaukee Maker Faire this year! A new place to show our stuff after the Mousetrap's 5th year of action at the New York Hall of science for the World Maker Faire.  However,  this is a very costly endeavor and this is how you, the individual $25 dollar contributor, can help make a difference.  Your support will prove that through the power of crowd funding we can bring large art projects to a town near you.
Our stretch goal to be achieved IF we reach our $8,000 goal and beyond. Year after year, we receive requests to set up this unique contraption at science, and education centers all over the United States. Clearly there is a desire for what the Mousetrap can bring to a community, but sadly 9 times out of 10 the connection never comes to fruition for lack of production funding.  Most organizations can offer about half of what is necessary for a successful production.  That means crew is never fully compensated for the endless hard work the Mousetrap requires, or we simply can't accept the gig. We know that this often is the case for other wonderful exhibits and projects that have the ability to ignite imagination and creativity.  We would like to start a network of resources that Makers, DIYers, Artists, basement scientist, and backyard builders can use to connect and coordinate with Science Centers, Museums, Maker & Mini-Maker Faires, and festivals in the hopes of sharing resources, funding, sponsorships and more to bring life enriching projects to people everywhere.
For more Information about the Mousetrap go here!

Taco Bike serves organic, local, sustainable breakfast tacos from a bicycle. Our mission is to change the world, one taco at a time. 
Taco Bike Migas Taco with Papas
As a social business, we want to use Taco Bike to promote organic food, animal welfare, bicycling, and sustainability. We have a double bottom line and measure our success in terms of the positive impact we have. We want to be carbon neutral, certified humane, and the South’s first certified organic restaurant. 
Alex Kown, Operations & Logistics Manager, Uber Nashville
We know that the best ingredients make the best food, which is why we’re using eggs from Vital Farms, cheese from the Rumiano family, flour from Bob's Red Mill, masa from Gold Mine Natural Foods, and as much local produce as possible. We also have close relationships with local organic farms Delvin Farms and Green Door Gourmet, and have found distribution channels for all of our ingredients.
Taco Bike Scratch-Made Blue Corn Tortillas
We're already serving up tacos all around town to our friends and to businesses upon request. We have the recipes down, have talked to all the right people, and are ready to press the "go" button. Taco Bike has even received a sponsorship from the Nashville Area Chamber of Commerce Board of Directors through their Pay it Forward Program.
We’re going to be set up Monday through Friday mornings along main commuter roads going into downtown Nashville. Our model is to expand by making more tacos and adding more locations. We'll be using Pop, a commercial kitchen in East Nashville, to prepare the tacos, then wrapping them in foil and putting them in a warmer to keep them piping hot. We plan on biking to the same locations every day so that people can make a habit of picking us up on their way to work.
Taco Bike Huevos Taco with salsas
Our menu is simple. $5 per taco including choice of salsa and extra cheese. We're considering carrying secret off-the-menu items like hash browns, tacos for dogs, extra tortillas, and organic orange juice, as well as seasonal off-the-menu items like fruit skewers.
Taco Bike is also vegetarian-friendly, vegan-friendly, and gluten-free-friendly. If you ever don't see what you need, feel free to ask. We're here to serve. We want to do the best we can to make everyone happy.
Taco Bike Menu
We are passionate about breakfast tacos, and we want to bring more of this amazing food to Nashville. Breakfast tacos aren't only delicious, but are a healthy start to your day when done right. We select our ingredients based on nutritional content, ethics, and, of course, taste, ensuring that you're getting the most out of the most important meal of the day.
Taco Bike Scratch-Made Flour Tortillas
By supporting Taco Bike, you’re also supporting the local businesses that we work with, like Pop, Halcyon Bike Shop, Green Fleet Bicycle Shop, Delvin Farms, and Green Door Gourmet. We're committed to working as locally as possible so that we can keep more money in the local economy and contribute to a more vibrant Nashville.
Taco Bike T-shirts
Taco Bike will be participating in 1% for the Planet, and donating a portion of our proceeds to local charities that champion our causes. Organizations we'd like to support include: Community Food Advocates, Farm in the City, Nashville Grown, the Nashville Bicycle Alliance, Walk/Bike Nashville, Music City Cycling, Urban Chicken Advocates of Nashville (UCAN), the Nashville Public Library Seed Fund, Ride for Reading, the Oasis Bike Workshop, and People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA).
Cayla Mackey, owner of Taco Bike, with a Surly Bill trailer
Your support will allow us to buy and build out a bike trailer, and help us cover our operating expenses during the first three months while we get rolling. Here's a breakdown of what funds will go toward: trailer bed ($750), trailer hitch ($300), trailer shipping ($200) trailer buildout ($2000), three months of kitchen rental ($900), restaurant equipment ($1000), organic certification ($1000), humane certification ($1000), carbon neutral certification ($1000), insurance ($300), sidewalk vending permit ($50), iPad and point of sale system ($300), other operating expenses ($1125).
Dave Pittman, branding mastermind and best boyfriend ever
Bring organic breakfast tacos to a street corner near you by backing us on Kickstarter and telling everyone you know. Back the bike and taco bout it. (Get it?!)
www.taco.bike | facebook.com/tacobikenash | twitter/instagram: @TacoBikeNash

We want to be the first certified organic and certified humane restaurant in the country. This is important to us because of what it stands for. We're voting with our feet. We're going out of our way to prove that we're doing the right thing so that we can educate others and encourage them to do the same. We're setting a good example. 

We'd be the first restaurant in the South to get certified organic, and only sixth in the county. We'd be the first certified humane restaurant in the South. These certifications come with their own timelines, limitations, and costs. Since Taco Bike doesn't fit neatly into a pre-described category, this process is a little unknown. We'd be pioneers! This is exciting and uncertain. We've spoken to the head of the USDA organics program, who is a supporter and himself an avid bicyclist. Everyone wants it to happen, and we're going to fight for it! By spearheading the process, we're also going to make it easier for other businesses and restaurants to follow in our footsteps.

The PantryChic™ Story:
It all began one cold December in a tiny New York City apartment with inventor and entrepreneur Nicole Sollazzo Lee struggling to bake the perfect batch of cookies for her friends and family.  Nicole grew up with fond memories of baking with her grandmother and wanted to replicate her “secret” cookie recipe.  After several less than perfect batches, a sink full of dishes and ingredients everywhere Nicole was left tired and frustrated.  She thought to herself, I wish I could just place a bowl under each ingredient canister, push a button and the exact amount of every ingredient would be dispensed.
Two patents, an award winning product designer, and a Silicon Valley design and engineering firm later, we are close to making Nicole’s dream a reality with the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™.  This product will represent a brand new category in the $2.0 Billion food preparation market but more importantly, it will help people the world over fall in love with baking again!
The Baker’s Dilemma – Why Measuring Matters:
So why did Nicole struggle with her cookies that fateful December day?  Whether you are an occasional home baker or a professional pastry chef, accurately measuring ingredients is critical. Due to the chemistry involved in baking, recipes require very precise measurements. The correct balance of ingredients will not only ensure that food turns out tasting great, but also that the ratios of ingredients produce the proper consistency and density. There is nothing worse than spending all your time preparing a recipe, to end up with a sub-par or even worse, an inedible finished product just because you didn’t measure properly.
Weighing ingredients is more accurate than using volume measures such as measuring cups and spoons, which is why professional bakers routinely weigh their dry ingredients to remove variability.  Despite this knowledge, many American home bakers still commonly use their measuring cups when preparing recipes because it's how they were taught and it’s easier than converting recipes from volume to weight.
The Measuring Experiment:
We conducted an experiment during a focus group including a mix of casual and experienced bakers. Two volunteers were selected and asked to measure 1 cup of flour from the same canister utilizing the same measuring cup. After each volunteer measured 1 cup of flour, we asked them to place their cup on a scale. What did we find? Each cup had a different weight. How might this affect your recipe? You may end up with a denser, dryer batter, or worse, a cake that collapses!
PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™:
Why is the PantryChic Store & Dispense System™ Unique?
The PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™ removes all the guesswork for you.  Use the unit of measure your recipe calls for and the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™ does the conversions for you for over 50 pre-programmed ingredients!  Now you can get the best of both worlds, accuracy without the complexity. Even better, you don't have all those extra measuring utensils and dirty countertops to clean because the PantryChic™ Store and Dispense System™ automatically dispenses precisely from the canister straight into your bowl.
How it works:
PantryChic's Advanced Technology - Bluetooth® 
The recipe preparation workflow has changed and computers, tablets and smartphones have become fixtures in the kitchen as more and more consumers go to the internet to look up recipes.  As a result, we thought it would be essential that Bluetooth® technology be integrated into the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™.
Bluetooth® integration takes the user experience a step further by allowing users to control their Store & Dispense System™ and facilitate a “recipe walk through” with Apps built for their various devices.  This will allow the user to:
Use their tablets to control the device
Easily 'walk through' a recipe with Apps that will instruct the user to insert each canister in the order the recipe calls for so it can dispense the proper amount of each ingredient without the user having to program anything into the system.
Track frequency of recipe use
Modify and store recipes according to user preferences
Development Progress:
We completed breadboard and "proof of concept" testing to identify the most efficient and effective dispensing mechanism...
We leveraged 3D Printing to test parts and build a Functioning Prototype...
We are fine-tuning the functional prototype to get it ready for tooling & manufacturing
Food Preparation Appliance Market Opportunity:
Like many entrepreneurs we began this journey trying to solve a common problem but through research we have found that the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™ represents a new category in a very attractive market:
•U.S. food prep appliance market grew 5% to $2.0B in 2012 (3% unit growth to 31 million units)*
•2% unit CAGR through 2017 to 34 million units*
•“Foodie culture,” slow economy and healthy eating trends have contributed to growth*
•Countertop mixers grew 8% in 2012 to 2.0 million units*
•Popular wedding registry items*
*Euromonitor International, February 2012
Why Kickstarter?
Baking has been around since humans learned to grind wheat and corn into flour.  Most of us eat at least one baked good every day, whether we start the day with pancakes, eat a sandwich for lunch, or spoil ourselves with a delicious cookie or cupcakes.  To accommodate our busy lifestyles the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™ will revolutionize the home baking experience by making it more convenient and consistent while minimizing clean up. We are confident that the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™ will help people fall in love with baking again!  We have decided to partner with Kickstarter to connect with you and those interested in bringing innovation to a space that hasn’t changed in more than a century.
We sincerely hope you become as passionate about the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™ as we are and invite you to participate in our journey as we strive to bring a modern approach to a traditional pastime.  We are very close to realizing our dream but need to raise funds to help finance further testing, validation and tooling for manufacturing.
Use of the Funds
We’ve set a goal of $50,000, to help us build the tooling for manufacturing and production of the PantryChic™ Store and Dispense System™ for an anticipated launch as soon as February 2015.
Every dollar raised by Kickstarter will go towards further testing, validation and tooling for manufacturing and packaging of the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™. 
Please Note: The money raised by our generous backers will only be transferred to PantryChic if the campaign reaches or exceeds its goal of $50,000 by the end of the campaign on Wednesday, August 27th at 8pm EST.
Rewards
Stretch Goals: 
Achieving our KickStarter goal will represent a significant milestone towards bringing the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™ to homes nationwide! By helping us unlock our stretch goals, you'll receive special perks that'll make your PantryChic Store & Dispense System even more convenient!   
Manufacturing & Timeline:
Our next step is to finalize the tooling and molds and lock in the components for the production devices including the custom chip boards, LED display, Bluetooth® connectivity and scale.Our developers will finalize the firmware and begin building apps to facilitate the recipe walk through. Once we are satisfied with our final prototype and confident that we can deliver a high quality product we will begin our first production run and ship our backers their PantryChic™ Store & Dispense Systems™.
Meet The Pantry Chic™ Team:
Meet the creators and contributors of the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™.President & Inventor, Nicole Sollazzo Lee has assembled an exceptional team with a wealth of knowledge and experience in product design, engineering, sales and marketing.Collectively the team has built and managed successful high profile brands for companies including Ford, Nike, Apple and Johnson & Johnson.
Nicole Sollazzo Lee – President and CEO of Nik of Time, Inc™.
Nicole, the inventor and founder of the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™, has over 11 years of successful sales and marketing experience in the healthcare and media industries with 3 major fortune 500 companies: Clear Channel Communications, Johnson & Johnson and da Vinci robotic surgical system maker Intuitive Surgical. A proud graduate of Villanova University, Nicole holds 2 US Patents and several sales awards for achieving exponential growth.
Angelika Schubert-Belle - Product Designer & Co-owner of Carbon Project, Inc.
Angelika co-founded Carbon Project Inc. in 2001, a strategic and experience based design consultancy offering a holistic approach to design and business. She bringsover 20 years of experience in brand strategy and product design working with brands such as: Ford, Nike, Black & Decker, and Whirlpool to name a few.
Angelika holds a Bachelor of Science Degree with Honors in Industrial Design from the Art Center College of Design USA. She has received over 12 international design excellence awards from competitions, such as IDSA, IF Awards and Design Innovations and is a holder of 12 international design patents.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Risks:
We have built a functional prototype, performed various degrees of performance testing and are well on the way to finalizing our production prototype. Our business model has been to leverage our strengths and partner with experts such as Focus Product Design to assist us in areas where we have less experience to ensure we hit our goals. At this stage of the development process we are confident that we will be able bring the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™ to market but recognize that there are several risks that could impact our timelines.

Production Prototype Testing – We test all our prototypes with over 50 ingredients to ensure that there are no functional issues that would preclude the device from working with a particular ingredient and to ensure that the device will perform properly with years of use. If any issues are discovered we may need to modify the design.

Parts and Tooling – Nik of Time, Inc. will own all of the tooling and molds required to produce the PantryChic™ Store & Dispense System™ but have contracted with several manufacturers to produce the parts and complete the final assembly. As we are dependent on our manufacturers to provide us with high quality parts there is always the risk of part shortages, delays and/or quality issues that could delay production. We have contingencies in place and backup suppliers to mitigate some of this risk.

Quality Control – Our manufacturers and project managers have assured us that proper processes are in place to ensure quality throughout the manufacturing process and each production unit will be tested before it is shipped to customers. If our manufacturers and partners do not meet our quality standards or if any design flaws are discovered in the production units it may delay the project as we take steps to address any issues.

campaign.story:
I am raising funds to buy 30 pounds of seed to restore 3.6 acres of native prairie habitat in Cannon Falls, MN (near Minneapolis, MN).  
Did you know that without bees, 75% of the food we eat would simply disappear?  Without bees, breakfast would be bland, lunch would be limited and dinner would be dismal. Bees pollinate more than 100 types of crops in the US, from the almonds in your granola to the berries atop your favorite dessert.  Over 75% of the food we eat is originally pollinated by bees. Yet US honey bee colonies are dying off at an average annual rate of 29.6%.  
Since learning more about the plight of the bees, I’ve personally become very interested in helping the cause.  At first I planned a small plot at my own house, but after further investigation, we've shifted the focus to instead restore a much larger 3.6 acre plot of family owned land near Cannon Falls, MN. We’ve worked extensively with the Xerces society (WWF of invertebrates) to understand the best seed mixture and application method.  If you decide to donate to this worthy cause, you will be restoring native prairie to a part of the country where it has largely disappeared, helping recreate critical habitat for endangered bumblebees, bees, and butterflies.  
This plot will never sprayed with harmful pesticides again. The progress we have made so far has involved preparing the site for seeding (see mowing video posted).  Seeding will take place late this fall and your contribution will go directly (and only) toward the purchase of the seeds.  We have self funded all other aspects of this project ourselves.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The only real risks to this investment is invasive species. The plot we are planting was previously inhabited by invasive brome grass, dandelions and clover. We have treated the field over the last 4 months to clear the field of these invasive species. In the next few years, we will selectively weed the plot to continue to maintain a productive prairie habitat free of invasives.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hi Folks,
Field is still kickin'.  We're continuing to see progression of the good plants and reduction in the invasive ones.  Right on cue this spring (as expected) we had an infestation of bug bane, which is a biennial species (shows up every other year).  We had to mow the field a couple days ago, which will likely be the only mowing we do this year.  Now that the prairie has had a year to develop, we really want to encourage everything to take root and thrive.    The big update from the field is that we were able to secure a grant from Monarch Watch, an NGO whose mission is to encourage the revegetation of milkweed throughout the US and bring the Monarch butterflies back from the brink!

updates.update_userinfo: Saving the Bees - One Bee at a Time
updates.update_content:
August 2015 Update
Hi backers and fellow BEE-lievers!  We've been busy all summer mowing the native prairie.  I write to report that we've had several infestations (normal) consisting of yellow rocket, queen annes lace and an as-yet unidentified species.  This is all normal - this is why we mow!  Over time (2 year process) the invasive species will eventually die off as their root systems cannot withstand repeated disturbance, while the deep-rooted prairie will eventually take over.  We've even seen evidence of our seeds flowering this fall!  The last time we were out there - we observed prairie drop seed and black eyed susan flowering here and there in the field.  We know the prairie is building strength and will eventually take over!  Next year more of the same (mowing) albeit with less frequency.  See below for some pictures since the last update in May.

Kraut Source is Mason jar kitchenware for making fermented foods like sauerkraut, natural pickles, kimchi, kefir, and more. It's stainless steel, dishwasher safe, and easy to use.
If you are already buying live-culture fermented foods, you know how expensive that can get. Kraut Source encourages the DIY, artisanal spirit by enabling home chefs to create gourmet fermented foods, economically.
Kraut Source is designed for singles and families of all sizes. It fits on wide-mouth Mason jars, so you can make pint, quart, or 2-quart size batches. It takes up little space, so you can have several batches going at the same time. Its elegant, streamlined design means that it will look really nifty on your counter top.
Naturally fermented foods like sauerkraut and pickles are gourmet superfoods. Whether you are following a raw, vegan, vegetarian, gluten-free, paleo, or somewhere-in-between diet, eating fermented foods on a daily basis is good for you because they contain probiotics, enzymes, and vitamins.
The Problem
We started fermenting the old-fashion way with a big crock and a rock to keep the vegetables submerged underneath the brine.  The "crock-n-rock" method was inconsistent, as some batches turned out good, and some spoiled.  The batches were so big that they could feed a whole village.  Then we also had to transfer them into many jars that cluttered up the fridge. Plus they were all the same flavor. Boring!
We wanted to make different varieties, try different spices, but it wasn't possible with the big crock. We also tried other methods ( such as filling a big plastic bag with water to keep the vegetables submerged, or using an airlock, or a jar within a jar) but there was no solution that was simple, elegant, and consistent.  That's why we created Kraut Source.
 The Solution
Successful lacto-fermentation requires 3 fundamental steps:
Carbon dioxide produced by the fermenting bacteria must be vented. If not vented, the container can actually explode.
Fresh air must be kept out because the health-promoting lactobacilli bacteria are anaerobic. Fresh air allows undesirable microbes to grow, tainting or ruining your ferment.
The vegetables must be kept completely submerged in the salt-water brine because exposed vegetables can rot.
Kraut Source beautifully fulfills these requirements:
Kraut Source uses a water moat to provide a one way seal that lets carbon dioxide escape.
The same water moat keeps new air from entering.
Kraut Source uses a compact spring press to push down and submerge the vegetables. The spring press works better than a weight (stone or glass hockey puck used in other fermentation systems) because the spring exerts several times more downward force.
Besides fulfilling the basic requirements, Kraut Source does more:
Convenient. It fits onto a wide-mouth mason jar, so when your fermentation is complete, just remove Kraut Source, attach a regular lid, and place in the fridge for storage.
Attractive. It has a sleek elegant design that looks good on your counter top.
Durable. It's made from heavy gauge stainless steel.
Food safe. Stainless steel and glass are two of the safest materials known.
Consistent. Produces batch after batch of gourmet quality fermented foods.
How it Works
Watch the video below for detailed instructions on using Kraut Source to create tasty, nutritious fermented superfoods.
PLAY

Endless Variety
There are endless varieties of fermented foods.  Nearly every culture has invented their own favorites. (German:sauerkraut, Korean: kimchi, South American: curtido, India: chutneys). Kraut Source opens the door to variety and creativity.  Impress your guests with unique homemade gourmet fermented recipes that cannot be found in any store.
Please help us reach our goal
We spent almost 2 years designing and refining Kraut Source.  Our mission is to make it fun and easy for everyone to make healthy and delicious fermented foods at home. Jonas Laughlin, owner of Laughlin's Bakery
MISSION 
Every community needs a great bakery, and in turn, every baker needs a community. My baking business, Laughlin's Bakery, has already been up and running profitably out of my home for over a year. We have hundreds of customers and have already reached thousands of people through our pop-up bake sales, busy catering schedule, and donations to local events and organizations. But it's time to move it into a physical retail space - one with roots in (and ties to) its neighborhood. Because I live in the artistic and vibrant Short North of Columbus, Ohio, I'd love to see my business established here, too. 
But because of the large up-front costs associated with starting a bakery (even a small one), we're going to need some help! Just buying used equipment for a basic operation will cost me at least $20,000. Then there's the store itself. I'm planning to lease, which will be about $1,000 a month minimum in this area. In addition, there are the costs associated with outfitting a commercial space for its purpose. I'll need a small fleet of people (architect, contractor, inspectors, etc.) to get the joint ready for you guys. Many of the critical parties have already been identified and are ready to break ground on this project.
A lot of the planning is contingent upon having the dough (not the yeasty kind) to actually do this, and so that's why I'm reaching out to you. Your contribution, no matter the size, will get me one step closer to making my bakery a Columbus institution that we can all be proud of.
THE PRODUCTS
People at our bake sales always ask me, "What's the best thing you have?" or "what's your favorite?" I always respond in the same way: "It's all good, and that's why I put my name on it."*
I've spent years testing and perfecting my recipes and techniques, and I'm proud to say that the end results are unlike anything else you can find in Columbus. From my double-glazed lemon madeleines...
....to my croissants...
...to my layer cakes...
...and Old World Christmas cookies....
...it really is all good! 
I am constantly expanding my menu, but our core offerings can be seen on our full website here. In addition to French and German breads, cookies, and pastries, I am also very interested in American classics - particularly those that I grew up loving in the South. I see no reason why madeleines and my grandmother's fresh coconut cake shouldn't share the same shelf space.
*for the record, my all-time favorite actually is that fresh coconut cake.
MY VISION
There's no denying that downtown Columbus has a lot of incredible specialty bakeries already. But what's missing is an everyday/all-occasion bakery, the type you can find at the heart of every small European community or town. Admittedly, I'm very influenced by that model - a spot that is in an ongoing dialogue with its neighborhood clientele, and a place where you will want to go for a snack or your sandwich bread for the week just as readily as for your mother's birthday cake. In that sense, it will be a hub of our community. The quality of the products and service, however, will also be excellent enough to attract attention from around the state and country. I firmly believe that.
GIVING BACK
Since I began this venture, I have been honored to donate my baked goods to all sorts of humanitarian causes, and that practice will not change once I move into the storefront. I have already made arrangements with BESA Columbus to ensure that our leftover breads, cakes, and cookies will be donated to the people and organizations in our area that need them most. 
CUSTOMER REVIEWS 
"Nothing but perfection with these cakes and pastries! Jonas uses only the best ingredients...some of which he pulls from his own garden." 
"Always a highlight of any party or event I attended, these cakes and pastries are as much a treat visually as they are flavorful." 
"Honestly the best baking and catering service in the central Ohio area! Jonas is excellent in the kitchen and delivered high quality, tasty treats. All of my guests praised Laughlin's and asked for these treats to be at every party! The service and care received was beyond the expected quality. I will have Laughlin's at every event I host! You should too!"
"Amazing red velvet cake for my daughter's birthday - the pecan frosting really made it special."
"Took a Buckeye cake to work for a birthday and 7 out of 7 people said it was the best cake they have ever had! It was brilliantly balanced in flavors, and super moist. Our biggest dessert critic usually thought chocolate cakes were too overpoweringly chocolate but she LOVED this one. Highly recommend to anyone!"
"Jonas made an amazing Buckeye Cake for a birthday party I was having. Everyone at the party could not stop talking about how delicious the cake was! Would highly recommend to anyone!" 
"Excellent baked goods made with exceptional attention to detail and lots of love. Laughlin Baked Goods never disappoint and always leave your taste buds wanting more. If you haven't indulged in one of these wonderful creations, you are truly missing out."
"Absolutely delicious brownies. Bought 200 for a graduation party. Each brownie was in its own paper cup, which made them easy for people to take. They went quickly - people loved them!"
"Just one word, "amazing!""
REWARDS 
Please see the sidebar for more detailed descriptions of our backer rewards, but the chart below summarizes what's in it for you!
OUR GOAL AND BEYOND
WE DID IT!!! In just 10 days, you all helped me reach my goal and ensure that this project will be funded. THANK YOU!!
But the campaign is not yet over, and any "overage" will be used to: 
fast-track renovations at our potential storefront space (more about that soon!)
purchase my "wish-list" equipment (a dough sheeter for layered pastry doughs & a deck oven for super crusty breads)  
develop and purchase packaging (boxes, bags, ribbon, etc.) for the treats
So please, continue to offer your support!

Yep, Big Dick.
Put simply, it’s a premium softball bat. Put another way, playing with a BIG DICK just might improve your game. See what we did there? That’s the essence of the BIG DICK brand. A quality product and a marketer’s dream. In addition to our trademarked tagline “are you swingin’ a BIG DICK?”, we have many other catchy phrases in the hopper. The fun-inducing word-play possibilities are endless!
The idea was one of those ah-ha! moments inspired by friendly trash talk during a softball game! Many of you probably remember the hugely successful “Big Johnson” t-shirts from the 1980’s and 1990’s. This is a similar concept based on creative product design and suggestive wordplay.
Softball and other recreational sports bring people together for friendship, camaraderie, competition and most of all FUN! Imagine the back-and-forth innuendos and double-entendres inspired by this uniquely named bat designed to deliver the goods. Let’s face it - you can’t step up to the plate with a bat named BIG DICK and not deliver!
Marketing isn’t cheap. Manufacturing isn’t cheap. Licensing isn’t cheap. The first goal of the project is to secure funding to be used to promote the product, gather a list of interested customers and approach US-based sporting goods manufacturers with the opportunity to manufacture and sell the BIG DICK brand.
Step one: Use Kickstarter to secure funds for the purpose of raising awareness to this new and edgy product design via targeted social media campaigns, keyword advertising and the Kickstarter and BigDickSoftballBats.com websites. Potential customers will be encouraged to show interest via our opt-in database of interested customers.
Step two: Upon successful promotion and market penetration, the hardcore data representing the information gathered via our campaigns will be utilized to lobby US-based sporting goods manufacturers to manufacture and sell the BIG DICK brand. It is our intention to manufacture the BIG DICK brand in the United States.
In both steps and in concert with our own marketing efforts and using the funds from our Kickstarter campaign, we will enlist the aid of a public relations agency as well as a professional marketing firm to manage additional campaigns as well as present the brand and data to interested parties for production and sales.
Our Kickstarter funds will be used to:
Retain professional, reputable marketing and public relations firm(s)
Targeted online marketing via social media and keyword pay-per-click campaigns in an effort to build a list of interested potential customers
Pursue manufacturing opportunities with US-based sporting goods manufacturers utilizing the data gathered in our marketing campaigns
Once manufacturing has been secured, we envision the BIG DICK brand being sold online via a dedicated website (or websites) with traffic driven by targeted keyword advertising, social media promotion, trade-related websites, print advertising and of course, word of mouth. Because of the racy nature of the brand, it is not intended to be an item sold in retail stores. Online sales of softball and baseball equipment reached $593 million dollars in 2013*. We believe that the Internet provides opportunities to market the BIG DICK brand in ways which have not been available in a traditional brick-and-mortar setting. Below is a broad overview of various channels driving sales:
Dedicated website sales
Social media campaigns on websites such as Facebook and Twitter
Targeted keyword advertising with Google, Yahoo, Bing and others
Small doses of print advertising in relevant trade publications
Word of mouth!
Targeted online marketing: We will utilize Google AdWords, Bing Ads, Yahoo Advertising Solutions and other similar online marketing options.
Social Media: Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, YouTube and other social media outlets
*Statista.com
Pricing has not been determined. However, the BIG DICK softball bat will be exceptionally high quality and compete in the premium category.
Softball and baseball bats are highly regulated in nearly every aspect of their design. This is for reasons of safety as well as keeping the playing field (pardon the pun) level. Things such as material composition, weight, length, and how fast a ball can come off the bat are all strictly regulated. Bats on the high end of the performance spectrum will obviously use higher quality materials in an effort to be as balanced and responsive as possible. We fully intend the BIG DICK bat to utilize the best materials to achieve the best performance among its peers in the industry.
YES! Our intellectual property (trademarks) with the United States Patent and Trademark Office cover all sporting good items that you swing. Future plans include branding and licensing for other items such as golf clubs, baseball bats, tennis rackets and more.
 See the sidebar for Reward details.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The first thing we hear when we talk about our brand (other than "that's freakin' brilliant!") is “who’s going to put that on their store shelf?” The answer is simple. As stated above, there is no intention (at this time) to sell the BIG DICK brand in brick-and-mortar stores. Our brand was developed with the sole intention of utilizing the power of the Internet for marketing and sales.

The other question we hear is that existing manufacturers may not want to associate a racy brand name such as BIG DICK with their company. Although this seems insurmountable to some, we see this as a minor hurdle. Why? Here are the two main reasons:

Private label branding: This is very common in manufacturing and the most likely scenario for the BIG DICK brand. Often, companies manufacture products that they may not associate with their own brand or they manufacture products for other companies who then sell the product as their own. For example, Toyota manufactures the Pontiac Vibe, which is the same vehicle as a Toyota Matrix, but Pontiac brands and sells the Vibe as their own.

Stand-alone model: In this less-likely scenario for our brand, this is defined as a manufacturer who uses a model name in conjunction with their own brand name. In other words, the BIG DICK line of softball bats would simply be a model offered by any given brand name manufacturer. Think Chevrolet Corvette or Dodge Ram. These are stand-alone models of a single brand.

campaign.story:
DEAR KICKSTARTER           
This project is to preserve and make easily available some of history’s greatest yet rarest photographic images.  I am referring to the personal photographs taken by servicemen and women during World War 2. While researching my father’s World War 2 history I noticed the abundance of personal World War 2 photos being sold on the open market.  Unfortunately these photos are taken out of the collections and albums that the servicemen and women put together many years ago.  Thousands of Soldiers, Sailors and Marines lugged their personal cameras tucked in beside their mess kits and rifles through the world at war and documented compelling images of comrades and landscapes from a unique and personal perspective.   These pictures show the soldiers as no war photo journalist could.  They show the private moments the goofy times and the tension leading to battle.  Some even show the heat of battle from the viewpoint of the person being shot at.  As the number of surviving men and women that participated in World War 2 dwindle down their personal photographic collections are disappearing. The photo albums, cigar boxes full of loose pictures, strips of negatives, medals, are being sold to the highest bidder.  Unfortunately most of these collections are not being kept intact. Photos are torn off of pages or removed from album sleeves and then sold again individually. The purpose of this project is to take intact collections, preserve them, scan them into digital files, and place them on the internet in an easy to search, easy to download repository for everyone to appreciate.
ABOUT THE PROJECT
Intact collections I already own will be scanned and digitally saved.  The items themselves will be placed in an archival environment.  The collection author, unit information and any other pertinent details will all be placed in the same digital files.  The digital files will backed up in the cloud in disparate locations to insure their permanence.  
The files will then be actively shared with web sites or individuals that commemorate the units if available and placed on the World War 2 photo archive site as a common research point and for anyone to enjoy and appreciate. What makes this effort truly different is that a strong effort will be made to reunite the photos and information in the files to the unit legacy sites.  This will provide a digital canvas worthy of these great images. 
HOW THIS PROJECT WILL MAKE AN IMPACT
There are many commemorative and tribute organizations and sites for our World War 2 veterans.  Many of these sites have no visual record of the people contained in the tributes.  This project will in its own way help alleviate that problem.  One success story is listed below.
Zamzam Survivors
An example of this effort is the Zamzam Story web site.  The Zamzam was a ship sunk by the Germans in 1941.  The survivors keep the story of the Zamzam alive with reunions, a web site and have authored books on the event. Even though there was a Life magazine photographer on board his camera was taken by the Germans when the passengers were taken prisoner.  So he only had pictures onboard the ship.  I acquired the collection of Charles W. Carr the Director of Operations for the Red Cross in Spain in 1941.  In researching his personal collection of photographs I discovered they contained the images of the Zamzam American survivors arriving in San Sebastian, Spain, on May 31, 1941.  I created high resolution scans of all 33 pictures and a newspaper article About Mr. Carr and shared them with the survivor group.   The photos are now on their website. 
Zamzam survivors
THIS IS OF IMMEDIATE IMPORTANCE
The collections protected carefully over the last 6 decades by their owners are very quickly dispersing, fragmenting and losing their historical context until there will be little left.  Some collections take months to reassemble scouring the internet, estate sales, etc.  Many pieces will never resurface but many do.  The time is now to make a positive step forward to saving these wonderful pieces of history.
TAKING ACTION
My goal is to raise $500.00 to purchase archival binders, negative sleeve holders, photo holders, and a scanner – printer to help physically preserve and record the images.   As more collections are acquired they will be posted also.  This will be an ongoing process.  The following collections having been acquired and will be scanned, archived, and posted.
Private John Boland Signal Corps attached to the 94th Infantry Division Saar- Rhineland Campaign.
Major James Sands executive Officer 3118th Signal Service Group Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force Paris and Frankfort HQ.  
Private Charles M Jones 70th Infantry Division European Theater of Operations. 
Lieutenant Commander Bryan Smith Captain of the USS Impeccable AM 320 Pacific Theater of Operations invasion of Okinawa. 
USS Broadbill AM 58 Unknown Sailor European Theater of Operations, Normandy Utah Beach invasion, Operation Dragoon Southern France.
Battleship Colorado BB 45 Unknown sailor Pacific Theater of Operations
Sergeant Bob Sadler 72nd fighter squadron thirteenth Air Force, Pearl Harbor, Iwo Jima survivor
The exciting progress made in connecting these collections to where they belong will be posted to the Archive site for all to follow.  The personal stories and unit histories will be placed on the site along with the photos to honor the collections and will be available to browse and download.
REWARDS
I am offering the following rewards for donations levels listed below.
5.00 amount 
Online acknowledgement on the donation wall on the World War 2 Archive website.
20.00 amount 
Online acknowledgement and a 8” x 10” contributor card suitable for framing.
50.00 and above
Online acknowledgement a contributor card                                               and a 11” x 14”  project poster.  One can pick the poster of their choice.

campaign.story: We are using this Kickstarter campaign to raise funds to purchase a beer and liquor license for the restaurant. We have applied to the state of Ohio for a license, but the wait time is about a year and a half before one can be issued by the state. In the state of Ohio, you can be issued licenses to sell alcohol through the state, or, you can purchase them from exiting businesses that no longer have a need for them. While going through the state is the least expensive way, the cost is approximately $1100, the length of time to wait for the license can hamper business. Purchasing the license from an existing business is very fast, (can be as quick as a week to transfer the license), but not very cost effective. Purchasing a license for just wine and beer is usually in the $15,000 range. Now, you may ask, why wouldn't we just wait it out and get the license for cheap? If we do that, we are missing out on introducing new guests to our restaurant because of the lack of alcohol. Friday and Saturday nights are our slowest shifts, and it can be traced to guests looking for a libation, which we can not provide. This also hurts the potential financial side of the business as well. If guests are going to other restaurants to get drinks, and not stopping by Jobu, we are not operating at full financial potential. By raising these funds, we will be able to buy the necessary licenses to serve the guests the beverages they want and provide our guests with an even better experience then they are already having.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The main risk for us in this campaign is that once we are fully funded, there won't be the licenses available to purchase, or they will be priced higher than normal, and we won't have all the money necessary. Our solution to this is putting our money aside daily to be used for just such a situation. We may not have the full amount required immediately, but with the successful funding of this campaign, we will be that much closer to our end goal, and be able to purchase the licenses that much quicker.

campaign.story:
Mollie has always dreamed of going to college- since elementary school she has worked for straight A's and stellar extracurricular activities in order to get into a top-notch school. With snark, sarcasm, and plenty of tears, Mollie has persevered through middle and high school, finally reaching senior year with great grades and her sanity (mostly) in tact. Unfortunately, there is an unforeseen beast Mollie did not expect:
Application fees.
Unbeknownst to Mollie and her family, high school students are required to PAY for the opportunity to be judged by a university, so that they can be deemed WORTHY of paying $40,000 a year to attend. Though financial aid is offered to attend, there is not much assistance for middle class families to APPLY to schools that charge 50 to 85 dollars per application (before factoring in the charges of sending ACT or AP scores). With 8 to 10 schools she wishes to apply to, Mollie frets over the cost to her family being too high before she has even picked out an overpriced shower-caddy for the communal bathrooms.
Mollie's father is willing to help, but with over 17 years of dealing with her snark, sarcasm, and plenty of tears, he more than deserves some help in any way possible. That is why for her birthday, Mollie is requesting that her friends and loved ones donate to this fund in lieu of a gift. While it may not be 'glamorous' or 'fun', it is a necessary part of fulfilling Mollie's ultimate dream of going to a wonderful college, and simply must be paid!
This goal will not cover ALL of the application fees, but is certainly a start and would help Mollie and her father greatly in this time of stress, hair pulling, and insomnia present with college applications. Help this young woman accomplish her dreams, because if some guy can raise 60,000 dollars to make potato salad, Mollie should be able to pay for her freaking college applications.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There are inherently risks associated with applying to college. There is ALWAYS the chance that I will make some stupid mistake when filling out my applications, but I plan to have my wonderful college counselors edit my work on the Common Application before any are submitted. There is also the chance that I will get tired and simply decide not to fill out my college applications. Luckily for me in the event of this occurring my father has purchased a water gun to spray at me in order to wake me up and force me to finish my college applications. I also have a large supply of caffeinated beverages to keep me awake and a subscription to Netflix to keep me motivated. 

Finally, there is always the risk that even AFTER I submit all of my beautiful applications I will not get accepted to any colleges because the world is a cruel and unforgiving mistress. In this event, Mollie will weep for several days or weeks before becoming a travelling hobo and making her way to Disney Land where she will attempt to seek refuge in Cinderella castle without security noticing. Mollie will be sure to write frequent Facebook updates of her adventures living illegally on Disney Land grounds, as she is about 80% sure that there is free WiFi there.

updates.update_content:
Hello Everyone!
Well, as Miley Cyrus says (and truly Miley is never wrong), everybody makes mistakes, and nobody's perfect. This very obviously includes me, since 90% of the time I am a neurotic mess that is able to figure out how a buffer would react to the addition of a weak acid, but not read directions. Hey, with little sleep and lots of coffee, it happens to the best of us.
So, it turns out that Kickstarter was not the right place for my project. To be honest, when I thought of online fundraising, my mind first went here. I did look through the rules, but perhaps I was so blinded in the excitement of starting a new project or so inexperienced after a summer off that I did not really understand it. Either way, apparently I did not follow the guidelines set forth because my project does not end in a final product. Kickstarter is kicking me out.

WOW. Just, wow. I must be the only senior preparing for the first day back to class tomorrow that is in a GOOD mood today, and it's all thanks to you guys. I never expected this level of generosity, and I am so, so grateful to everyone. I hope you all know what a HUGE deal this is to me, and what a weight it has taken off of my shoulders this year. From the bottom of my heart, (yes, contrary to popular belief I'm pretty sure I do have a heart), I just want to say thank you. 

SO, we've made the $650 needed to apply to every college on the ever-famous list! And send them my ACT scores! And bribe the admissions office to admit the neurotic crazy girl sitting outside the campus cuddling a chemistry textbook! (okay, there probably isn't enough money in the world for that one- unfortunately). So what's next for this Kickstarter campaign? 

Well, while we're on a roll I say we keep on rolling. I have more things to give, and my father has more college expenses that make him sigh rather loudly whenever I mention them. The next one? The infamous college visits!

I would like to visit my top two schools, currently Brown University and Barnard College, before November 1st to decide if/where I want to apply Early Decision. Getting up to Providence and New York is not free however, because as much as I love the wizarding world of Harry Potter I have YET to acquire a portkey or learn to apparate without leaving my elbows behind. I've done some calculations (because what else do we nerds do), and in our little Toyota Matrix it would cost about $175 round trip in gas money. (for those skeptics that don't believe me, it's all calculated here: )  Since that email I received last week that I was an heir to an oil tycoon I had never met in Saudi Arabia turned out to be a hoax, we'll be paying full price for our gas.

campaign.story:
SkyscraperFarms began as a student start-up at The Ohio State University as a part of the Wolstein Scholars Program. A prototype system was completed in which a trial run was conducted with a variety of produce. Results from the initial prototype can be found below.
Romaine lettuce beginning to sprout.
Young looseleaf lettuce growing within a grow plug.
Mature head of romaine lettuce.
Mature basil plant.
Since the conclusion of its involvement with the program in May 2014, SkyscraperFarms is looking to once again create an aeroponic system to produce fresh local greens, but this time, it will be capable of producing nearly 60 units of produce each week. Each week, about 24 heads of lettuce, 12 heads of spinach, 9 heads of kale, 6 bunches of arugula, as well as 3 bunches of basil, rosemary, cilantro, and oregano can be harvested (amounts may vary proportionally). The produce harvested from the system will then be sold, with the environment of a private farmer's market in mind. The system alone will only take up approximately 32 sq. ft. and will have two vertical levels. A drawing of the aeroponic system can be found below. 
Drawing of the new aeroponic system.
In order to construct the next aeroponic system, SkyscraperFarms will be exchanging fresh produce as well as new growing systems to cover the start-up costs. The resources earned through Kickstarter will be used to purchase additional light fixtures and equipment, as well as initial consumables such as nutrients and growing media. The goal of our Kickstarter represents the minimum requirement for completing the new aeroponic system and being able to begin production. A rough distribution of startup costs is provided below.
Pie chart displaying the distribution of start-up costs.
Any additional funding received will be used to expand the original design accordingly. We would also like to donate 10% of the produce grown and harvested from our system to the Mid-Ohio Foodbank to provide residents of our community with the healthy greens they need. 
Ultimately, SkyscraperFarms would like to provide residents of urban areas with fresh local produce without the problems found within traditional agriculture. Our produce is grown with natural and organic nutrient solutions, and do not require the use of any pesticides. Climate-controlled growing areas allow for consistent, optimal harvests that can be enjoyed by the local community.
We hope you can be part of our next step forward!

campaign.story:
CodeOfKindness.com, is a new and innovative way of helping spread kindness throughout the world. Users are able to see exactly where their good deeds have had an impact.
The concept:
Special tokens with unique codes imprinted on them are passed from one person to the next whenever an act of kindness is either witnessed or performed. If the token holder does an act of kindness for someone, they pass it to the person they were kind to in hopes that that person will do the same for someone else. In the second case, the token holder may give it to someone they saw perform an act of kindness. Either way, the object is to keep a token moving so that its presence helps continue to motivate acts of kindness. 
Why it is unique:
The unique aspect of Code Of Kindness is that people can actually see where kindness has spread and what impact it has had. As a token is passed from one person to the next, it is up to the token holder to log in its unique code at CodeOfKindness.com. They also have the option to provide a brief description of how they came to receive it. Whenever someone visits the website they can then see where the token has been and who it was passed to and why.

Hopebeacon employs Datzing’s cutting edge technology to help people worldwide innovate and maximize their efforts in supporting and promoting any charitable or meaningful causes. The Hopebeacon empowers individuals and charities to attain greater awareness and support in their community by effortlessly sharing advocacy and enabling spontaneous donations from any mobile while on the move. With Hopebeacon, you wear and champion your cause wherever you go.
The more people that know about the power of Hopebeacon, the greater the impact! Please help us spread the word!
Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram
High Rez Video available @ http://vimeo.com/98225948

campaign.story:
UPDATE: We have stretch goals! This is what we will do with everything we raise over the $40,000:
1. We are going to build a cookbook library (open to anyone). Shelves, books (oh the books!), and buy some comfortable chairs.

2. If we get to $50,000, we are going to build an official demonstration kitchen station so all makers and guests can have the best experience with the cooking classes, workshops, and more. There will be equipment (the more money, the better this part will be) so our food and drink makers (and you!) can record quality demonstrations, vlogs, cooking shows, etc. 

Okay... here is our story:

Food brings people together, nourishes bodies and souls, and creates a wealth of economic opportunities for everyone from local growers to cooks, bakers, and roasters. The Commissary is a place created especially for people that love, work with, and live all things food and drink.
The Commissary is:
A commercial kitchen, storage, and event space for hire;
a co-working space for food makers;
a base camp for small businesses; and
a connection point for the Central Ohio food community. 
In the beginning...
The Commissary began as an idea of where culinary student Kate wanted to be instead of classroom kitchens.
Kate: When I was in culinary school, I had dreams of opening a butcher shop that would make stocks, sausages, and basic mise en place out of local ingredients. I wanted chefs and farmers and produce companies to be able to experiment in that space. I plotted out all of the parts of the business that I still needed to learn before jumping in, and then life intervened. I’ve worked my way through that list since. 
When my first son was born, I made all of his baby food with ingredients from my favorite farms. I looked into selling the food at a farmers’ market, but regulations require all frozen foods be prepared and stored in a commercial kitchen. At the time, I couldn’t find any restaurants that were willing to let me rent space in the off hours. The light bulb flickered back on and ever since I have been making plans and meeting people who need this space to happen just as much as I want it to.
At first, The Commissary was going to be in a gorgeous space on Town St in Franklinton, but after some time I had to acknowledge that the fit was not right. At the same time, Steve and I started talking more seriously about a partnership.
Steve: For nearly a decade I worked in an asset management office where I provided financial, administrative, and compliance services for a number of independent representatives. Essentially, my job was to enable those representatives to focus on the core aspects of building their businesses. For all of those years, I drove by 1400 Dublin Road every day and imagined the possibilities of that space. After a big career change into the food truck world and time spent working next to other truck owners, I realized that many food makers need that same sort of back office support and 1400 Dublin Road would be the perfect place to make that happen.
Together, we have made The Commissary a place where the possibilities include: 
Entrepreneurial chefs can try out new dishes and gain the experience they need to open their own restaurants with substantially less financial risk. 
Cooks and bakers will be able to teach a variety of classes covering everything from theory to hands-on techniques.
Established restaurants can experiment with new concepts or create special meals for a select clientele without disrupting their establishment.
Community organizations, companies, and decision makers can meet, taste, network, and work on ways to make our city safer, happier, and more delicious.
Entrepreneurs can share their experiences, ask questions, and get support from the community.
There are so many more things that can happen, like team building activities, community outreach, networking events, private parties, photo shoots and marketing, and on and on…
In creating The Commissary, we want to contribute to the energy and momentum of the food community in Columbus and open doors to growth as yet only imagined. That said, it truly does take a village to get our dream off the ground, and we couldn't have gotten this far without all of those people who believed in us, helped us get established, and continue to help us grow. We look forward to a lifetime of bringing people together over food, and to growing our list of partners—both in profession and in spirit—day by day, week by week, year after year. We hope you join us.
Why Kickstarter?
We have been working on The Commissary for a while. When we began planning out all of the spaces in The Commissary, another business was partnering with us to complete a spectacular tasting room/event space. When they needed to slow their timeline down and ultimately pull out of the project, we were left with so much possibility and not enough room in the budget to make everything happen. Be our partner! Let’s work together to make this exciting space a reality. 
Construction is really progressing on over 2000 sq ft of kitchen space, an experimental brewery, and roasting space; the storage space for equipment, trucks, carts, and inventory; co-working office spaces; and more. We need you in order to create the belly of the business: a space for the community to gather, network, learn, collaborate, taste... 
A quick peek at our plans (note: these drawings are a few months old and some great changes have been made, including a bigger common space)
This Kickstarter fundraiser is all or *gulp* nothing: if we don't reach our goal, we will not receive any of the donations pledged, your credit card will not be charged, and the special dining events we have planned will not happen as scheduled. If we do reach our goal (yay!), your credit card will be charged when the campaign ends on July 10th. To the right you'll find a list of rewards and special dining events for different levels of pledges. Please help us take this space from a dream and turn it into a reality! 
How will the money be spent? 
Where we want to end up (the top) and where we are right now (the bottom)
We have a 1200 sq ft construction zone to convert into a community space before anyone gets to gather and dine: 
Tables and chairs
China, glassware, flatware
Lighting and interior finishes
AV equipment 
Demonstration equipment
Beer taps and cooler
Licenses and permits
It all adds up. The more we can gather, the more we can share with the diverse community that will fill this space.
We will be working with local craftsmen and craftswomen (and some successful Kickstarters) to make this community event space perfectly local. For example, Griffen Hollow Studios has been designing tables that will make you want to pull up a chair. They will also be carving the names and messages of each of our supporters into wooden spoons to be hung up in a great big public display of our affection – I mean art. Affectionate art, perhaps. Alison Rose will be screenprinting some swag. Valerie Starr is one of the local artists that will be filling our walls with lovely art. Igloo Letterpress's beautiful prints will beautifying our walls (and possibly yours too!).
The architectural plans have already been approved and construction of the kitchens in The Commissary is moving so fast. We have food makers committed to fill this event space calendar with all manner of special dining experiences. 
When will the parties start? 
June/July: Construction of The Commissary continues. 
August: Fill the kitchens with equipment, the event space with tables, pass our final inspections, and host a helluva grand opening party! 
September/October: Special dining events begin! 
Thank you for taking the time to learn about The Commissary and our fundraising campaign. We are so excited about seeing this space transform into a gathering place for the community and are grateful for your support. For real.
Kate & Steve

This beautiful 8.5x11 limited-edition print is hand-printed on French Paper Company coverstock. It was lovingly set by the presswomen at Igloo Letterpress using antique wood and lead type and pulled on a 1942 Vandercook #4 press.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Every project has potential obstacles. These are a few risks to The Commissary's community space:

Kitchen incubators are fairly young as far as business concepts go. We have done extensive research, toured several facilities around the state, and talked with even more around the country. We have made many of our business decisions and forecasts by drawing on our business experiences, feedback from our networks, and this research. However, we don't know enough about the long term challenges for kitchen incubators to know what we don't know yet. 

We are building a business based on serving small businesses. Their problems are our problems. We want to create an environment that presents those businesses with many opportunities to grow and thrive. To do so means that we can only be as successful as the businesses that fill our kitchens.

Marble Cliff is willing to take a chance on a kitchen incubator and food truck base camp in their safe village boundaries. The Commissary will need to prove itself as a good neighbor to any that may be nervous we may be too loud or smelly. Not doing so could result in limitations on our business.

updates.update_content:
It has been awhile since we posted anything over here so let me fix that now!
We have been open for 10 months! 10 of the craziest, most unpredictable months I have ever experienced. Most of them have been good - maybe not June - but the rest have been fun.

There are over 50 food businesses and makers that use The Commissary at least once a month and even more that use our kitchens for occasional events or seasonally. A few of our clients have already grown up and into the next stage of their business - whether that be a new brick and mortar or an expanded network of retail locations.

Woah. This Kickstarter is about to wrap up in just 5 more hours. I feel great about what we have accomplished. Do you? 

There are $3,473 to raise in order to meet our stretch goals. A demonstration kitchen station would be a great asset to our mission: education, community outreach, expansion, experimentation, and play. We have our eye on a certain area in our space for a cookbook library. During last night's tweet-up, we decided that any cookbook library would be incomplete if we did not also have a cake pan library. So, if you know someone who may be interested or is waiting for something, maybe let them know about the deadline is a coming.
